pages.title: Talent/Commissions Information
pages.short_description: Any human anywhere will blossom in a hundred unexpected talents and capacities simply by being given the opportunity to do so.Doris Lessing

pages.title: Actors
pages.short_description: All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely players. William Shakespeare, As You Like It

pages.title: Ambassadors/Freelance Marketing/Social Media
pages.short_description: I believe that every person is born with talent. Maya Angelou

pages.title: Curators
pages.short_description: I don't think there is any truth. There are only points of view. Allen Ginsberg

pages.title: Photographers/Artists/Graphic Designers
pages.short_description: We do not remember days, we remember moments. Cesare Pavese

pages.title: Filmmakers
pages.short_description: “Film as dream, film as music. No art passes our conscience in the way film does, and goes directly to our feelings, deep down into the dark rooms of our souls.” Ingmar Bergman

pages.title: Writers
pages.short_description: “Authors like cats because they are such quiet, lovable, wise creatures, and cats like authors for the same reasons.” Robertson Davies

pages.title: Howl by Allen Ginsberg
pages.short_description: I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness

pages.title: The Nose  by Nikolai Vasilievich Gogol
pages.short_description: “Perfect nonsense goes on in the world. Sometimes there is no plausibility at all” Nikolai Gogol, The Nose

pages.title: White Nights by Fyodor Dostoyevsky
pages.short_description: “It was a marvelous night, the sort of night one only experiences when one is young. The sky was so bright, and there were so many stars that, gazing upward, one couldn’t help wondering how so many whimsical, wicked people could live under such a sky.”

pages.title: The Yellow Wallpaper by Charlotte Perkins Gilman
pages.short_description: If a physician of high standing, and one’s own husband, assures friends and relatives that there is really nothing the matter with one but temporary nervous depression—a slight hysterical tendency—what is one to do? . . .So I take phosphates or phosphites—whichever it is, and tonics, and journeys, and air, and exercise, and am absolutely forbidden to “work” until I am well again. Personally I disagree with their ideas . . .

pages.title: Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen
pages.short_description: “A lady's imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to matrimony in a moment.” Jane Austen, Pride and Prejudice

pages.title: Sense and Sensibility by Jane Austen
pages.short_description: “I come here with no expectations, only to profess, now that I am at liberty to do so, that my heart is and always will be yours.” Jane Austen, Sense and Sensibility

pages.title: Northanger Abbey by Jane Austen
pages.short_description: “Beware how you give your heart.” Jane Austen, Northanger Abbey

pages.title: Emma by Jane Austen
pages.short_description: “Were I to fall in love, indeed, it would be a different thing; but I have never been in love ; it is not my way, or my nature; and I do not think I ever shall.” Jane Austen, Emma

pages.title: Persuasion by Jane Austen
pages.short_description: “You pierce my soul. I am half agony, half hope...I have loved none but you.” Jane Austen, Persuasion

pages.title: Mansfield Park by Jane Austen
pages.short_description: “Life seems but a quick succession of busy nothings.” Jane Austen, Mansfield Park

pages.title: Jane Eyre - An autobiography by Charlotte Brontë
pages.short_description: I am not an angel, I asserted; and I will not be one till I die: I will be myself. Charlotte Bronte, Jane Eyre

pages.title: Wuthering Heights by Emily Brontë
pages.short_description: If all else perished, and he remained, I should still continue to be; and if all else remained, and he were annihilated, the universe would turn to a mighty stranger.Emily Bronte, Wuthering Heights

pages.title: The Moonstone by Wilkie Collins
pages.short_description: 'In this matter of the Diamond,' he said, 'the characters of innocent people have suffered under suspicion already—as you know. The memories of innocent people may suffer, hereafter, for want of a record of the facts to which those who come after us can appeal. There can be no doubt that this strange family history of ours ought to be told.'

pages.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray by Oscar Wilde
pages.short_description: “The books that the world calls immoral are books that show the world its own shame.” Oscar Wilde, The Picture of Dorian Gray

pages.title: Great Expectations by Charles Dickens
pages.short_description: “I loved her against reason, against promise, against peace, against hope, against happiness, against all discouragement that could be.” Charles Dickens, Great Expectations

pages.title: Bleak House by Charles Dickens
pages.short_description: “There were two classes of charitable people: one, the people who did a little and made a great deal of noise; the other, the people who did a great deal and made no noise at all.” Charles Dickens, Bleak House

pages.title: Utopia  by Thomas More
pages.short_description: “For if you suffer your people to be ill-educated, and their manners to be corrupted from their infancy, and then punish them for those crimes to which their first education disposed them, what else is to be concluded from this, but that you first make thieves and then punish them.” Thomas More, Utopia

pages.title: A Little Princess by Frances Hodgson Burnett
pages.short_description: Whatever comes, she said, cannot alter one thing. If I am a princess in rags and tatters, I can be a princess inside. It would be easy to be a princess if I were dressed in cloth of gold, but it is a great deal more of a triumph to be one all the time when no one knows it. Frances Hodgson Burnett, A Little Princess

pages.title: Metamorphosis by Franz Kafka
pages.short_description: “I cannot make you understand. I cannot make anyone understand what is happening inside me. I cannot even explain it to myself.” Franz Kafka, The Metamorphosis

pages.title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll
pages.short_description: But I don’t want to go among mad people, Alice remarked. Oh, you can’t help that, said the Cat: we’re all mad here. I’m mad. You’re mad. How do you know I’m mad? said Alice. You must be, said the Cat, or you wouldn’t have come here. Lewis Carroll, Alice in Wonderland

pages.title: Gone With the Wind by Margaret Mitchel
pages.short_description: Burdens are for shoulders strong enough to carry them. Margaret Mitchell, Gone with the Wind

pages.title: Much Ado About Nothing by William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more, Men were deceivers ever,- One foot in sea and one on shore, To one thing constant never. William Shakespeare, Much Ado About Nothing

pages.title: Romeo and Juliet by William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: “My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep; the more I give to thee, The more I have, for both are infinite.” William Shakespeare, Romeo and Juliet

pages.title: The Age of Innocence by Edith Wharton
pages.short_description: “Each time you happen to me all over again.” Edith Wharton, The Age of Innocence

pages.title: The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald
pages.short_description: “And so with the sunshine and the great bursts of leaves growing on the trees, just as things grow in fast movies, I had that familiar conviction that life was beginning over again with the summer.”F. Scott Fitzgerald, The Great Gatsby

pages.title: Little Women by Louisa May Alcott
pages.short_description: “I like good strong words that mean something…” Louisa May Alcott, Little Women

pages.title: The Scarlet Letter by Nathaniel Hawthorne
pages.short_description: “We dream in our waking moments, and walk in our sleep.” Nathaniel Hawthorne, The Scarlet Letter

pages.title: Tess of the d'Urbervilles by Thomas Hardy
pages.short_description: “A strong woman who recklessly throws away her strength, she is worse than a weak woman who has never had any strength to throw away.” Thomas Hardy, Tess of the D'Urbervilles

pages.title: Strange case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde by Robert Louis Stevenson
pages.short_description: “Quiet minds cannot be perplexed or frightened but go on in fortune or misfortune at their own private pace, like a clock during a thunderstorm. ” Robert Louis Stevenson, The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde

pages.title: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer by Mark Twain
pages.short_description: “Tom said to himself that it was not such a hollow world, after all. He had discovered a great law of human action, without knowing it -- namely, that in order to make a man or a boy covet a thing, it is only necessary to make the thing difficult to attain.” Mark Twain, The Adventures of Tom Sawyer

pages.title: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain
pages.short_description: “Human beings can be awful cruel to one another.” Mark Twain, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn

pages.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
pages.short_description: “Never trust to general impressions, my boy, but concentrate yourself upon details.” Arthur Conan Doyle, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes

pages.title: Moby Dick by Herman Melville
pages.short_description: “As for me, I am tormented with an everlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on barbarous coasts.” Herman Melville, Moby-Dick; or, The Whale

pages.title: The Prince by Niccolo Machiavelli
pages.short_description: “Everyone sees what you appear to be, few experience what you really are.” Niccolò Machiavelli, The Prince

pages.title: The Importance of Being Earnest by Oscar Wilde
pages.short_description: “The good ended happily, and the bad unhappily. That is what Fiction means.” Oscar Wilde, The Importance of Being Earnest

pages.title: Dracula by Bram Stoker
pages.short_description: “Once again...welcome to my house. Come freely. Go safely; and leave something of the happiness you bring.” Bram Stoker, Dracula

pages.title: Peter Pan by J. M. Barrie
pages.short_description: “All the world is made of faith, and trust, and pixie dust.” J.M. Barrie, Peter Pan

pages.title: Frankenstein by Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley
pages.short_description: “Nothing is so painful to the human mind as a great and sudden change.” Mary Shelley, Frankenstein

pages.title: Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse
pages.short_description: “Wisdom cannot be imparted. Wisdom that a wise man attempts to impart always sounds like foolishness to someone else ... Knowledge can be communicated, but not wisdom. One can find it, live it, do wonders through it, but one cannot communicate and teach it.” Hermann Hesse, Siddhartha

pages.title: A Doll's House: a play by Henrik Ibsen
pages.short_description: “I must make up my mind which is right – society or I.” Henrik Ibsen, A Doll's House

pages.title: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave by Frederick Douglass
pages.short_description: I have observed this in my experience of slavery, - that whenever my condition was improved, instead of its increasing my contentment, it only increased my desire to be free, and set me to thinking of plans to gain my freedom.

pages.title: The Hound of the Baskervilles by Arthur Conan Doyle
pages.short_description: “presume nothing” Arthur Conan Doyle, The Hound of the Baskervilles

pages.title: Beyond Good and Evil by Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche
pages.short_description: “Madness is something rare in individuals — but in groups, parties, peoples, and ages, it is the rule.” Friedrich Nietzsche, Beyond Good and Evil

pages.title: War and Peace by Leo Tolstoy
pages.short_description: “We can know only that we know nothing. And that is the highest degree of human wisdom.” Leo Tolstoy, War and Peace

pages.title: The Jungle Book by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: And he grew and grew strong as a boy must grow who does not know that he is learning any lessons, and who has nothing in the world to think of except things to eat Rudyard Kipling, The Jungle Book

pages.title: Far from the Madding Crowd by Thomas Hardy
pages.short_description: “It is difficult for a woman to define her feelings in language which is chiefly made by men to express theirs.” Thomas Hardy, Far from the Madding Crowd

pages.title: Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin by Benjamin Franklin
pages.short_description: “Never confuse Motion with Action.” Benjamin Franklin, Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin

pages.title: Heart of Darkness by Joseph Conrad
pages.short_description: “It was written I should be loyal to the nightmare of my choice.” Joseph Conrad, Heart of Darkness

pages.title: Oliver Twist by Charles Dickens
pages.short_description: “Please, sir, I want some more.” Charles Dickens, Oliver Twist

pages.title: The Life and Adventures of Robinson Crusoe by Daniel Defoe
pages.short_description: “Thus fear of danger is ten thousand times more terrifying than danger itself.” Daniel Defoe, Robinson Crusoe

pages.title: The Time Machine by H. G. Wells
pages.short_description: “We should strive to welcome change and challenges, because they are what help us grow. With out them we grow weak like the Eloi in comfort and security. We need to constantly be challenging ourselves in order to strengthen our character and increase our intelligence. ” H.G. Wells, The Time Machine

pages.title: Around the World in Eighty Days by Jules Verne
pages.short_description: “Anything one man can imagine, other men can make real.” Jules Verne, Around the World in 80 Days

pages.title: The Story of My Life by Helen Keller
pages.short_description: “One can never consent to creep when one feels an impulse to soar.” Helen Keller, The Story of My Life

pages.title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Washington Irving
pages.short_description: “There is a sacredness in tears....They are the messengers of overwhelming grief, of deep contrition and of unspeakable love.” Washington Irving

pages.title: The Secret Adversary by Agatha Christie
The Mysterious Affair at Styles by Agatha Christie
pages.short_description: “To all those who lead monotonous lives in the hope that they may experience at second hand the delights and dangers of adventure. Agatha Christie, The Secret Adversary

pages.title: Complete Original Short Stories of Guy De Maupassant by Guy de Maupassant
pages.short_description: “There is only one good thing in life, and that is love.” Guy de Maupassant, The Complete Short Stories of de Maupassant

pages.title: Through the Looking-Glass by Lewis Carroll
pages.short_description: “If I had a world of my own, everything would be nonsense. Nothing would be what it is, because everything would be what it isn't. And contrary wise, what is, it wouldn't be. And what it wouldn't be, it would. You see?” Lewis Carroll, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland & Through the Looking-Glass

pages.title: Pygmalion by Bernard Shaw
pages.short_description: “What is life but a series of inspired follies? The difficulty is to find them to do. Never lose a chance: it doesn’t come every day.” George Bernard Shaw, Pygmalion

pages.title: The Prince and the Pauper by Mark Twain
pages.short_description: “When I am king they shall not have bread and shelter only, but also teachings out of books, for a full belly is little worth where the mind is starved.” Mark Twain, The Prince and the Pauper

pages.title: David Copperfield by Charles Dickens
pages.short_description: “My meaning simply is, that whatever I have tried to do in life, I have tried with all my heart to do well; that whatever I have devoted myself to, I have devoted myself to completely; that in great aims and in small, I have always been thoroughly in earnest.” Charles Dickens, David Copperfield

pages.title: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz by L. Frank Baum
pages.short_description: “Never give up...No one knows what's going to happen next.” L. Frank Baum

pages.title: The Woman in White by Wilkie Collins
pages.short_description: “The best men are not consistent in good—why should the worst men be consistent in evil?” Wilkie Collins, The Woman in White

pages.title: The War of the Worlds by H. G. Wells
pages.short_description: That this world was being watched keenly and closely by intelligences greater than man's and yet as mortal as his own; that as men busied themselves about their various concerns they were scrutinised and studied, perhaps almost as narrowly as a man with a microscope might scrutinise the transient creatures that swarm and multiply in a drop of water.” H.G. Wells, The War of the Worlds

pages.title: Don Quixote by Miguel de Cervantes
pages.short_description: “Finally, from so little sleeping and so much reading, his brain dried up and he went completely out of his mind.” Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra, Don Quixote

pages.title: Madame Bovary by Gustave Flaubert
pages.short_description: “Human speech is like a cracked kettle on which we tap crude rhythms for bears to dance to, while we long to make music that will melt the stars.” Gustave Flaubert, Madame Bovary

pages.title: This Side of Paradise by F. Scott Fitzgerald
pages.short_description: “They slipped briskly into an intimacy from which they never recovered.” F. Scott Fitzgerald, This Side of Paradise

pages.title: The Trial by Franz Kafka
pages.short_description: “It's only because of their stupidity that they're able to be so sure of themselves.” Franz Kafka, The Trial

pages.title: The Idiot by Fyodor Dostoyevsky
pages.short_description: “It is better to be unhappy and know the worst, than to be happy in a fool's paradise.” Fyodor Dostoyevsky, The Idiot

pages.title: Women in Love by D. H. Lawrence
pages.short_description: “But better die than live mechanically a life that is a repetition of repetitions.” D.H. Lawrence, Women in Love

pages.title: The Pursuit of God by A. W. Tozer
pages.short_description: “We need never shout across the spaces to an absent God. He is nearer than our own soul, closer than our most secret thoughts” A.W. Tozer, The Pursuit of God

pages.title: A Room with a View by E.M. Forster
pages.short_description: “We cast a shadow on something wherever we stand, and it is no good moving from place to place to save things; because the shadow always follows. Choose a place where you won't do harm - yes, choose a place where you won't do very much harm, and stand in it for all you are worth, facing the sunshine.” E.M. Forster, A Room with a View

pages.title: The Man in the Iron Mask by Alexandre Dumas
pages.short_description: “Does the open wound in another's breast soften the pain of the gaping wound in our own? Or does the blood which is welling from another man's side staunch that which is pouring from our own? Does the general anguish of our fellow creatures lessen our own private and particular anguish? No, no, each suffers on his own account, each struggles with his own grief, each sheds his own tears.” Alexandre Dumas, The Man in the Iron Mask

pages.title: The Iliad by Homer
pages.short_description: “Let me not then die ingloriously and without a struggle, but let me first do some great thing that shall be told among men hereafter.” Homer, The Iliad

pages.title: The Odyssey by Homer
pages.short_description: “Of all creatures that breathe and move upon the earth, nothing is bred that is weaker than man.” Homer, The Odyssey

pages.title: A Respectable Woman by Kate Chopin
pages.short_description: “She wanted something to happen - something, anything: she did not know what.” Kate Chopin

pages.title: Miss Brill by Katherine Mansfield
pages.short_description: “She had become really quite expert, she thought, at listening as though she didn't listen, at sitting in other people's lives just for a minute while they talked round her.”  Katherine Mansfield, Miss Brill

pages.title: The princess by D. H. Lawrence
pages.short_description: “Be still when you have nothing to say; when genuine passion moves you, say what you've got to say, and say it hot.” D.H. Lawrence

pages.title: Zodmirsky's Duel by Alexandre Dumas
pages.short_description: There is neither happiness nor misery in the world; there is only the comparison of one state with another, nothing more. He who has felt the deepest grief is best able to experience supreme happiness. We must have felt what it is to die, Morrel, that we may appreciate the enjoyments of life. Live, then, and be happy, beloved children of my heart, and never forget, that until the day God will deign to reveal the future to man, all human wisdom is contained in these two words, 'Wait and Hope. Alexandre Dumas

pages.title: Prelude by Katherine Mansfield
pages.short_description: Risk anything! Care no more for the opinion of others ... Do the hardest thing on earth for you. Act for yourself. Face the truth. Katherine Mansfield

pages.title: The Happy Prince by Oscar Wilde
pages.short_description: “Any place you love is the world to you.” Oscar Wilde, The Happy Prince

pages.title: The Mark on the Wall by Virginia Woolf
pages.short_description: PERHAPS it was the middle of January in the present that I first looked up and saw the mark on the wall. In order to fix a date it is necessary to remember what one saw.

pages.title: The dance of death by Gustave Flaubert
pages.short_description: At night in winter, when the snow-flakes fall slowly from heaven like great white tears, I raise my voice; its resonance thrills the cypress trees and makes them bud anew.

pages.title: Eveline by James Joyce
pages.short_description: SHE sat at the window watching the evening invade the avenue. Her head was leaned against the window curtains and in her nostrils was the odour of dusty cretonne. She was tired.

pages.title: Winter dreams by F. Scott Fitzgerald
pages.short_description: Dexter is a self-made man: he has used his wits to make a fortune. However, the implication of the term self-made man is that you have made yourself from scratch, that you have no origin point except your own talents and skills. So the new Dexter is, quite literally, a different man from the kid who used to caddy at the Sherry Island Golf Club. No wonder he is having some trouble with the gap which lay between his present and his past.

pages.title: A Haunted House by Virginia Woolf
pages.short_description: I want to think quietly, calmly, spaciously, never to be interrupted, never to have to rise from my chair, to slip easily from one thing to another, without any sense of hostility, or obstacle. I want to sink deeper and deeper, away from the surface, with its hard separate facts. Virginia Woolf, A Haunted House and Other Short Stories

pages.title: An Imaginative Woman by Thomas Hardy
pages.short_description: Marchmill considered his wife's likes and inclinations somewhat silly; she considered his sordid and material. The husband's business was that of a gunmaker in a thriving city northwards, and his soul was in that business always; the lady was best characterised by that superannuated phrase of elegance

pages.title: 'Freedom or Death' by Emmeline Pankhurst
pages.short_description: Men make the moral code and they expect women to accept it. They have decided that it is entirely right and proper for men to fight for their liberties and their rights, but that it is not right and proper for women to fight for theirs. Emmeline Pankhurst

pages.title: 'The Emancipation Proclamation' by Abraham Lincoln
pages.short_description: And by virtue of the power, and for the purpose aforesaid, I do order and declare that all persons held as slaves within said designated States, and parts of States, are, and henceforward shall be free; and that the Executive government of the United States, including the military and naval authorities thereof, will recognize and maintain the freedom of said persons. January 1, 1863

pages.title: 'Professions for Women' by Virginia Woolf
pages.short_description: In other words, now that she had rid herself of falsehood, that young woman had only to be herself. Ah, but what is herself? I mean, what is a woman? I assure you, I do not know, I do not believe that you know. Virginia Woolf, Professions for Women

pages.title: 'A Room of One's Own - Shakespeare's Sister' by Virginia Woolf
pages.short_description: “Lock up your libraries if you like; but there is no gate, no lock, no bolt that you can set upon the freedom of my mind.” Virginia Woolf, A Room of One's Own

pages.title: 'Wind of Change' by Harold MacMillan
pages.short_description: No one could fail to be impressed with the immense material progress which has been achieved. That all this has been accomplished in so short a time is a striking testimony to the skill, energy and initiative of your people.

pages.title: 'Weapons for squalid and trivial ends' by Aneurin Bevan
pages.short_description: In the history of nations, there is no example of such frivolity.

pages.title: 'The lady's not for turning' by Margaret Thatcher
pages.short_description: To those waiting with bated breath for that favourite media catchphrase, the U-turn, I have only one thing to say, you turn if you want to. The lady's not for turning

pages.title: 'The flame of French resistance' by Charles de Gaulle
pages.short_description: Whatever happens, the flame of French resistance must not and shall not die.

pages.title: 'On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences' by Nikita Khrushchev
pages.short_description: Lenin always stressed the role of the people as the creator of history, the directing and organisational roles of the party as a living and creative organism, and also the role of the central committee.

pages.title: 'Inaugural Address' by Franklin D. Roosevelt
pages.short_description: So, first of all, let me assert my firm belief that the only thing we have to fear is fear itself.

pages.title: 'I am Prepared to Die' by Nelson Mandela
pages.short_description: “During my lifetime I have dedicated myself to this struggle of the African people. I have fought against white domination, and I have fought against black domination. I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. It is an ideal which I hope to live for and to achieve. But if needs be, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die.” Nelson Mandela

pages.title: 'I Have a Dream' by Dr. Martin Luther King
pages.short_description: I have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin, but by the content of their character. Martin Luther King, Jr.

pages.title: We Shall Fight on the Beaches' by Winston Churchill
pages.short_description: We shall defend our Island, whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender

pages.title: 'Inaugural Address' by John F. Kennedy
pages.short_description: My fellow Americans, ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country.

pages.title: Gettysburg Address' by Abraham Lincoln
pages.short_description: A new nation, conceived in Liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.”,Abraham Lincoln, The Gettysburg Address

pages.title: A Tryst with Destiny' by Jawaharlal Nehru
pages.short_description: Action to be effective must be directed to clearly conceived ends.

pages.title: As I Ponder'd in Silence. by Walt Whitman
pages.short_description: AS I ponder'd in silence, Returning upon my poems, considering, lingering long, A Phantom arose before me, with distrustful aspect, Terrible in beauty, age, and power

pages.title: One's-Self I Sing. by Walt Whitman
pages.short_description: ONE'S-SELF I sing-a simple, separate Person; Yet utter the word Democratic, the word En-masse.

pages.title: Song at Sunset. by Walt Whitman
pages.short_description: SPLENDOR of ended day, floating and filling me! Hour prophetic-hour resuming the past! Inflating my throat-you, divine average! You, Earth and Life, till the last ray gleams, I sing.  Open mouth of my Soul, uttering gladness

pages.title: Thoughts. by Walt Whitman
pages.short_description: OF the visages of things—And of piercing through   to the accepted hells beneath;  Of ugliness—To me there is just as much in it as   there is in beauty—And now the ugliness of   human beings is acceptable to me;

pages.title: I Hear America Singing. by Walt Whitman
pages.short_description: I HEAR America singing, the varied carols I hear; Those of mechanics-each one singing his, as it should be, blithe and strong

pages.title: Pioneers! O Pioneers! by Walt Whitman
pages.short_description: COME, my tan-faced children, Follow well in order, get your weapons ready; Have you your pistols? have you your sharp edged axes? Pioneers! O pioneers!

pages.title: O Captain! My Captain! by Walt Whitman
pages.short_description: O CAPTAIN! my Captain! our fearful trip is done; The ship has weather'd every rack, the prize we sought is won; The port is near, the bells I hear, the people all exulting, While follow eyes the steady keel, the vessel grim and daring: But O heart! heart! heart! O the bleeding drops of red

pages.title: Born Yesterday by Philip Larkin
pages.short_description: Tightly folded bud, I have wished you something None of the others would: Not the usual stuff About being beautiful, Or running off a spring Of innocence or love

pages.title: Vers de Societe by Philip Larkin
pages.short_description: My wife and I have asked a crowd of craps To come and waste their time and ours: perhaps You'd care to join us? In a pig's arse, friend. Day comes to an end.

pages.title: I Remember, I Remember by Philip Larkin
pages.short_description: Coming up England by a different line For once, early in the cold new year, We stopped, and, watching men with number plates Sprint down the platform to familiar gates, 'Why, Coventry!' I exclaimed. 'I was born here.'

pages.title: This Be The Verse by Philip Larkin
pages.short_description: They fuck you up, your mum and dad. They may not mean to, but they do. They fill you with the faults they had And add some extra, just for you.  But they were fucked up in their turn By fools in old-style hats and coats,

pages.title: High Windows by Philip Larkin
pages.short_description: When I see a couple of kids And guess he's fucking her and she's Taking pills or wearing a diaphragm, I know this is paradise

pages.title: If by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: If you can keep your head when all about you Are losing theirs and blaming it on you; If you can trust yourself when all men doubt you, But make allowance for their doubting too

pages.title: The Prodigal Son by Rudyard Kipling by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: Here come I to my own again, Fed, forgiven and known again, Claimed by bone of my bone again And cheered by flesh of my flesh.

pages.title: An American by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: If the Led Striker call it a strike, Or the papers call it a war, They know not much what I am like, Nor what he is, My Avatar.  Throuh many roads, by me possessed, He shambles forth in cosmic guise; He is the Jester and the Jest, And he the Text himself applies.

pages.title: The Answer by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: A Rose, in tatters on the garden path, Cried out to God and murmured 'gainst His Wrath, Because a sudden wind at twilight's hush Had snapped her stem alone of all the bush.

pages.title: Arithmetic on the Frontier by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: A great and glorious thing it is To learn, for seven years or so, The Lord knows what of that and this, Ere reckoned fit to face the foe -- The flying bullet down the Pass, That whistles clear: 'All flesh is grass.'

pages.title: The Man Who Would Be King by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: The Law, as quoted, lays down a fair conduct of life, and one not easy to follow. I have been fellow to a beggar again and again under circumstances which prevented either of us finding out whether the other was worthy. I have still to be brother to a Prince, though I once came near to kinship with what might have been a veritable King

pages.title: As the Bell Clinks by Rudyard Kipling
pages.short_description: As I left the Halls at Lumley, rose the vision of a comely Maid last season worshipped dumbly, watched with fervor from afar;

pages.title: She Walks in Beauty by Byron
pages.short_description: She walks in beauty, like the night Of cloudless climes and starry skies; And all that's best of dark and bright Meet in her aspect and her eyes: Thus mellowed to that tender light Which heaven to gaudy day denies.  One shade the more, one ray the less

pages.title: Mending Wall by Robert Frost
pages.short_description: omething there is that doesn't love a wall, That sends the frozen-ground-swell under it, And spills the upper boulders in the sun; And makes gaps even two can pass abreast.

pages.title: Mowing by Robert Frost
pages.short_description: There was never a sound beside the wood but one, And that was my long scythe whispering to the ground. What was it it whispered? I knew not well myself; Perhaps it was something about the heat of the sun, Something, perhaps, about the lack of sound- And that was why it whispered and did not speak. It was no dream of the gift of idle hours

pages.title: After Apple-Picking by Robert Frost
pages.short_description: My long two-pointed ladder's sticking through a tree Toward heaven still, And there's a barrel that I didn't fill Beside it, and there may be two or three Apples I didn't pick upon some bough. But I am done with apple-picking now. Essence of winter sleep is on the night

pages.title: Birches by Robert Frost
pages.short_description: When I see birches bend to left and right Across the lines of straighter darker trees, I like to think some boy's been swinging them.

pages.title: Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening by Robert Frost
pages.short_description: Whose woods these are I think I know. His house is in the village, though; He will not see me stopping here To watch his woods fill up with snow.

pages.title: Nothing Gold Can Stay by Robert Frost
pages.short_description: Nature's first green is gold, Her hardest hue to hold. Her early leaf's a flower; But only so an hour. Then leaf subsides to leaf. So Eden sank to grief, So dawn goes down to day. Nothing gold can stay.

pages.title: The Road Not Taken by Robert Frost
pages.short_description: Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, And sorry I could not travel both And be one traveler, long I stood And looked down one as far as I could To where it bent in the undergrowth; Then took the other

pages.title: Lady Lazarus by Sylvia Plath
pages.short_description: I have done it again. One year in every ten I manage it-  A sort of walking miracle, my skin Bright as a Nazi lampshade, My right foot  A paperweight, My face a featureless, fine Jew linen.  Peel off the napkin O my enemy. Do I terrify?-  The nose, the eye pits, the full set of teeth? The sour breath

pages.title: You're by Sylvia Plath
pages.short_description: Clownlike, happiest on your hands, Feet to the stars, and moon-skulled, Gilled like a fish. A common-sense Thumbs-down on the dodo's mode. Wrapped up in yourself like a spool, Trawling your dark as owls do. Mute as a turnip from the Fourth Of July to All Fools' Day, O high-riser, my little loaf.

pages.title: Ariel by Sylvia Plath
pages.short_description: Stasis in darkness. Then the substanceless blue Pour of tor and distances.  God's lioness, How one we grow, Pivot of heels and knees! - The furrow  Splits and passes, sister to The brown arc Of the neck I cannot catch

pages.title: Daddy by Sylvia Plath
pages.short_description: You do not do, you do not do Any more, black shoe In which I have lived like a foot For thirty years, poor and white, Barely daring to breathe or Achoo.  Daddy, I have had to kill you.

pages.title: The Applicant by Sylvia Plath
pages.short_description: First, are you our sort of a person? Do you wear A glass eye, false teeth or a crutch, A brace or a hook, Rubber breasts or a rubber crotch,  Stitches to show something's missing? No, no? Then How can we give you a thing? Stop crying. Open your hand.

pages.title: The Moon and the Yew Tree by Sylvia Plath
pages.short_description: This is the light of the mind, cold and planetary. The trees of the mind are black. The light is blue. The grasses unload their griefs on my feet as if I were God, Prickling my ankles and murmuring of their humility. Fumy, spirituous mists inhabit this place Separated from my house by a row of headstones.

pages.title: The Young Soldier by Wilfred Owen
pages.short_description: It is not death Without hereafter To one in dearth Of life and its laughter,  Nor the sweet murder Dealt slow and even Unto the martyr Smiling at heaven:  It is the smile Faint as a (waning) myth, Faint, and exceeding small On a boy's murdered mouth.

pages.title: Dulce Et Decorum Est by Wilfred Owen
pages.short_description: Bent double, like old beggars under sacks, Knock-kneed, coughing like hags, we cursed through sludge, Till on the haunting flares we turned our backs And towards our distant rest began to trudge. Men marched asleep.

pages.title: Anthem For Doomed Youth by Wilfred Owen
pages.short_description: What passing-bells for these who die as cattle? Only the monstrous anger of the guns. Only the stuttering rifles' rapid rattle Can patter out their hasty orisons. No mockeries for them; no prayers nor bells, Nor any voice of mourning save the choirs,  The shrill, demented choirs of wailing shells;

pages.title: Smile, Smile, Smile by Wilfred Owen
pages.short_description: Head to limp head, the sunk-eyed wounded scanned Yesterday's Mail; the casualties

pages.title: The Last Laugh by Wilfred Owen
pages.short_description: O Jesus Christ! I'm hit,' he said; and died. Whether he vainly cursed, or prayed indeed, The Bullets chirped - 'In vain! vain! vain!' Machine-guns chuckled, 'Tut-tut! Tut-tut!' And the Big Gun guffawed.  Another sighed, - 'O Mother, Mother! Dad!' Then smiled, at nothing, childlike, being dead.

pages.title: Stanzas Written On The Road Between Florence and Pisa by Byron
pages.short_description: Oh, talk not to me of a name great in story; The days of our youth are the days of our glory

pages.title: When We Two Parted by Byron
pages.short_description: When we two parted In silence and tears, Half broken-hearted, To sever for years, Pale grew thy cheek and cold, Colder thy kiss; Truly that hour foretold Sorrow to this.

pages.title: Darkness by Byron
pages.short_description: I had a dream, which was not all a dream. The bright sun was extinguished, and the stars Did wander darkling in the eternal space, Rayless, and pathless, and the icy earth Swung blind and blackening in the moonless air;

pages.title: The Dream by Byron
pages.short_description: I  Our life is twofold; Sleep hath its own world, A boundary between the things misnamed Death and existence: Sleep hath its own world, And a wide realm of wild reality

pages.title: Solitude by Byron
pages.short_description: To sit on rocks, to muse o'er flood and fell, To slowly trace the forest's shady scene, Where things that own not man's dominion dwell, And mortal foot hath ne'er or rarely been;

pages.title: Oh! Snatched Away In Beauty's Bloom by Byron
pages.short_description: Oh! snatched away in beauty's bloom, On thee shall press no ponderous tomb; But on thy turf shall roses rear Their leaves, the earliest of the year; And the wild cypress wave in tender gloom:

pages.title: There Be None of Beauty's Daughters by Byron
pages.short_description: There be none of Beauty's daughters With a magic like Thee; And like music on the waters Is thy sweet voice to me: When, as if its sound were causing The charm?d ocean's pausing, The waves lie still and gleaming, And the lull'd winds seem dreaming:

pages.title: A Birthday by Christina Rossetti
pages.short_description: My heart is like a singing bird Whose nest is in a water'd shoot; My heart is like an apple-tree Whose boughs are bent with thickset fruit; My heart is like a rainbow shell That paddles in a halcyon sea; My heart is gladder than all these Because my love is come to me.

pages.title: A Better Resurrection by Christina Rossetti
pages.short_description: I have no wit, no words, no tears; My heart within me like a stone Is numbed too much for hopes or fears. Look right, look left, I dwell alone;

pages.title: Remember by Christina Rossetti
pages.short_description: Remember me when I am gone away, Gone far away into the silent land; When you can no more hold me by the hand,

pages.title: In An Artist's Studio by Christina Rossetti
pages.short_description: ne face looks out from all his canvasses, One selfsame figure sits or walks or leans; We found her hidden just behind those screens, That mirror gave back all her loveliness.

pages.title: Winter: My Secret by Christina Rossetti
pages.short_description: I  tell my secret? No indeed, not I: Perhaps some day, who knows? But not today; it froze, and blows, and snows, And you're too curious: fie! You want to hear it? well:

pages.title: I Heard A Fly Buzz-When I Died- by Emily Dickinson
pages.short_description: I heard a Fly buzz-when I died- The Stillness in the Room

pages.title: Because I Could Not Stop For Death- by Emily Dickinson
pages.short_description: Because I could not stop for Death- He kindly stopped for me- The Carriage held but just Ourselves- And Immortality.

pages.title: For each ecstatic instant by Emily Dickinson
pages.short_description: For each ecstatic instant We must an anguish pay In keen and quivering ratio To the ecstasy.

pages.title: Hope is the thing with feathers by Emily Dickinson
pages.short_description: Hope is the thing with feathers That perches in the soul, And sings the tune--without the words, And never stops at all

pages.title: I felt a cleaving in my mind by Emily Dickinson
pages.short_description: I felt a cleaving in my mind As if my brain had split; I tried to match it, seam by seam, But could not make them fit.

pages.title: I Died For Beauty-But Was Scarce by Emily Dickinson
pages.short_description: I died for Beauty-but was scarce Adjusted in the Tomb When One who died for Truth, was lain In an adjoining room-  He questioned softly 'Why I failed?' 'For Beauty,' I replied- 'And I-for Truth-Themself are One-

pages.title: There's a certain Slant of light by Emily Dickinson
pages.short_description: There's a certain Slant of light,  Winter Afternoons -  That oppresses

pages.title: The Tyger by William Blake
pages.short_description: Tyger, Tyger burning bright In the forests of the night, What immortal hand or eye Could frame thy fearful symmetry?

pages.title: London by William Blake
pages.short_description: I wander thro' each charter'd street. Near where the charter'd Thames does flow A mark in every face I meet Marks of weakness, marks of woe.  In every cry of every Man.

pages.title: Jerusalem: England! awake! awake! awake! by William Blake
pages.short_description: OF Public Opinion; Of a calm and cool fiat, sooner or later, (How impassive! How certain and final!) Of the President with pale face, asking secretly to himself, What will the people say

pages.title: The Ecchoing Green by William Blake
pages.short_description: The Sun does arise, And make happy the skies. The merry bells ring, To welcome the Spring.

pages.title: The Chimney Sweeper (Experience) by William Blake
pages.short_description: A little black thing among the snow: Crying weep, weep, in notes of woe! Where are thy father & mother? say? They are both gone up to the church to pray.  Because I was happy upon the heath. And smil'd among the winters snow: They clothed me in the clothes of death.

pages.title: The Nurse's Song (Innocence) by William Blake
pages.short_description: When voices of children are heard on the green And laughing is heard on the hill, My heart is at rest within my breast And everything else is still  Then come home my children the sun is gone down And the dews of night arise

pages.title: Holy Thursday (Experience) by William Blake
pages.short_description: Is this a holy thing to see. In a rich and fruitful land. Babes reduced to misery. Fed with cold and usurous hand?  Is that trembling cry a song? Can it be a song of joy? And so many children poor? It is a land of poverty!

pages.title: Three Things to Remember by William Blake
pages.short_description: A Robin Redbreast in a cage, Puts all Heaven in a rage.  A skylark wounded on the wing Doth make a cherub cease to sing  He who shall hurt the little wren Shall never be beloved by men

pages.title: Musee des Beaux Arts by W. H. Auden
pages.short_description: About suffering, they were never wrong, The Old Masters: how well they understood

pages.title: A Walk After Dark by W. H. Auden
pages.short_description: A cloudless night like this Can set the spirit soaring: After a tiring day

pages.title: O tell me the truth about love by W. H. Auden
pages.short_description: Some say love's a little boy, And some say it's a bird, Some say it makes the world go around

pages.title: O what is that sound by W. H. Auden
pages.short_description: O what is that sound which so thrills the ear Down in the valley drumming, drumming? Only the scarlet soldiers, dear, The soldiers coming.

pages.title: Funeral Blues by W. H. Auden
pages.short_description: Stop all the clocks, cut off the telephone, Prevent the dog from barking with a juicy bone, Silence the pianos and with muffled drum

pages.title: The Unknown Citizen by W. H. Auden
pages.short_description: This Marble Monument Is Erected by the State)  He was found by the Bureau of Statistics to be One against whom there was no official complaint

pages.title: In my Craft or Sullen Art by Dylan Thomas
pages.short_description: In my craft or sullen art Exercised in the still night When only the moon rages And the lovers lie abed With all their griefs in their arms, I labour by singing light

pages.title: And Death Shall Have No Dominion by Dylan Thomas
pages.short_description: And death shall have no dominion. Dead mean naked they shall be one With the man in the wind and the west moon; When their bones are picked clean and the clean bones gone

pages.title: Fern Hill by Dylan Thomas
pages.short_description: Now as I was young and easy under the apple boughs About the lilting house and happy as the grass was green, The night above the dingle starry, Time let me hail and climb

pages.title: Do not go gentle into that good night by Dylan Thomas
pages.short_description: Do not go gentle into that good night, Old age should burn and rave at close of day; Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

pages.title: Ballad Of The Long-Legged Bait by Dylan Thomas
pages.short_description: The bows glided down, and the coast Blackened with birds took a last look At his thrashing hair and whale-blue eye; The trodden town rang its cobbles for luck.  Then good-bye to the fishermanned

pages.title: In Country Sleep by Dylan Thomas
pages.short_description: Never and never, my girl riding far and near In the land of the hearthstone tales, and spelled asleep, Fear or believe that the wolf in a sleepwhite hood

pages.title: In the White Giant's Thigh by Dylan Thomas
pages.short_description: Through throats where many rivers meet, the curlews cry Under the conceiving moon, on the high chalk hill, And there this night I walk in the white giant's thigh

pages.title: The Ball Poem by John Berryman
pages.short_description: What is the boy now, who has lost his ball, What, what is he to do? I saw it go Merrily bouncing, down the street, and then

pages.title: The Traveller by John Berryman
pages.short_description: They pointed me out on the highway, and they said 'That man has a curious way of holding his head.'  They pointed me out on the beach; they said 'That man Will never become as we are, try as he can.

pages.title: The Curse by John Berryman
pages.short_description: Cedars and the westward sun. The darkening sky. A man alone Watches beside the fallen wall The evening multitudes of sin Crowd in upon us all.

pages.title: Dream Song 14: Life, friends, is boring by John Berryman
pages.short_description: Life, friends, is boring. We must not say so. After all, the sky flashes, the great sea yearns, we ourselves flash and yearn

pages.title: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock by T.S. Eliot
pages.short_description: Let us go then, you and I, When the evening is spread out against the sky Like a patient etherised upon a table; Let us go, through certain half-deserted streets, The muttering retreats Of restless nights in one-night cheap hotels

pages.title: Portrait of a Lady by T. S. Eliot
pages.short_description: Thou hast committed-- Fornication: but that was in another country And besides, the wench is dead.

pages.title: The Hollow Men by T.S. Eliot
pages.short_description: We are the hollow men We are the stuffed men Leaning together Headpiece filled with straw. Alas! Our dried voices, when We whisper together Are quiet and meaningless

pages.title: Macavity - The Mystery Cat by T. S. Eliot
pages.short_description: Macavity's a Mystery Cat: he's called the Hidden Paw-- For he's the master criminal who can defy the Law. He's the bafflement of Scotland Yard, the Flying Squad's despair: For when they reach the scene of crime--Macavity's not there!

pages.title: Four Quartets by T. S. Eliot
pages.short_description: Time present and time past  Are both perhaps present in time future,  And time future contained in time past.  If all time is eternally present  All time is unredeemable.

pages.title: The Waste Land by T.S. Eliot
pages.short_description: “And I will show you something different from either Your shadow at morning striding behind you Or your shadow at evening rising to meet you I will show you fear in a handful of dust. T.S. Eliot, The Waste Land

pages.title: The Thought-Fox by Ted Hughes
pages.short_description: I imagine this midnight moment's forest: Something else is alive Beside the clock's loneliness And this blank page where my fingers move.  Through the window I see no star:

pages.title: Orf by Ted Hughes
pages.short_description: Because his nose and face were one festering sore That no treatment persuaded, month after month, And his feet four sores, the same, Which could only stand and no more,  Because his sickness was converting his growth

pages.title: Old Age Gets Up by Ted Hughes
pages.short_description: Stirs its ashes and embers, its burnt sticks  An eye powdered over, half melted and solid again Ponders Ideas that collapse At the first touch of attention  The light at the window, so square and so same So full-strong as ever, the window frame A scaffold in space, for eyes to lean on

pages.title: Thistles by Ted Hughes
pages.short_description: Against the rubber tongues of cows and the hoeing hands of men Thistles spike the summer air And crackle open under a blue-black pressure.  Every one a revengeful burst Of resurrection

pages.title: I Do Not Love You Except Because I Love You by Pablo Neruda
pages.short_description: I do not love you except because I love you; I go from loving to not loving you, From waiting to not waiting for you My heart moves from cold to fire.  I love you only because it's you the one I love; I hate you deeply, and hating you Bend to you, and the measure of my changing love for you Is that I do not see you but love you blindly.

pages.title: Drunk As Drunk by Pablo Neruda
pages.short_description: Drunk as drunk on turpentine From your open kisses, Your wet body wedged Between my wet body and the strake Of our boat that is made of flowers

pages.title: If You Forget Me by Pablo Neruda
pages.short_description: I want you to know one thing.  You know how this is: if I look at the crystal moon, at the red branch of the slow autumn at my window, if I touch near the fire the impalpable ash or the wrinkled body of the log, everything carries me to you

pages.title: Walking Around by Pablo Neruda
pages.short_description: It so happens I am sick of being a man. And it happens that I walk into tailorshops and movie houses dried up, waterproof, like a swan made of felt steering my way in a water of wombs and ashes.

pages.title: Tonight I Can Write by Pablo Neruda
pages.short_description: Tonight I can write the saddest lines.  Write, for example, 'The night is starry and the stars are blue and shiver in the distance.'  The night wind revolves in the sky and sings.

pages.title: The Red Lacquer Music-Stand by Amy Lowell
pages.short_description: A music-stand of crimson lacquer, long since brought In some fast clipper-ship from China, quaintly wrought With bossed and carven flowers and fruits in blackening gold

pages.title: Lilacs by Amy Lowell
pages.short_description: Lilacs, False blue, White Purple, Colour of lilac, Your great puffs of flowers Are everywhere in this my New England. Among your heart-shaped leave

pages.title: Patterns by Amy Lowell
pages.short_description: I walk down the garden paths, And all the daffodils Are blowing, and the bright blue squills. I walk down the patterned garden-paths In my stiff, brocaded gown.

pages.title: The Green Bowl by Amy Lowell
pages.short_description: This little bowl is like a mossy pool In a Spring wood, where dogtooth violets grow Nodding in chequered sunshine of the trees; A quiet place, still, with the sound of birds

pages.title: He Wishes for the Cloths of Heaven by William Butler Yeats
pages.short_description: Had I the heavens' embroidered cloths,  Enwrought with golden and silver light,  The blue and the dim and the dark cloths  Of night and light and the half-light,  I would spread the cloths under your feet

pages.title: Easter 1916 by William Butler Yeats
pages.short_description: I have met them at close of day  Coming with vivid faces  From counter or desk among grey  Eighteenth-century houses.  I have passed with a nod of the head  Or polite meaningless words,

pages.title: Leda and the Swan by William Butler Yeats
pages.short_description: A sudden blow: the great wings beating still  Above the staggering girl, her thighs caressed  By the dark webs, her nape caught in his bill,  He holds her helpless breast upon his breast.

pages.title: Sailing to Byzantium by William Butler Yeats
pages.short_description: THAT is no country for old men. The young  In one another's arms, birds in the trees  - Those dying generations - at their song

pages.title: The Lake Isle of Innisfree by William Butler Yeats
pages.short_description: I will arise and go now, and go to Innisfree,  And a small cabin build there, of clay and wattles made;  Nine bean-rows will I have there, a hive for the honey-bee,  And live alone in the bee-loud glade.

pages.title: The Second Coming by William Butler Yeats
pages.short_description: Turning and turning in the widening gyre  The falcon cannot hear the falconer;  Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold;  Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world,  The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere

pages.title: When You are Old by William Butler Yeats
pages.short_description: When you are old and grey and full of sleep,  And nodding by the fire, take down this book,  And slowly read, and dream of the soft look  Your eyes had once, and of their shadows

pages.title: Robin Hood by John Keats
pages.short_description: TO A FRIEND  No! those days are gone away  And their hours are old and gray,  And their minutes buried all  Under the down-trodden pall  Of the leaves of many years:  Many times have winter's shears,  Frozen North, and chilling East

pages.title: La Belle Dame Sans Merci by John Keats
pages.short_description: I  Oh what can ail thee, knight-at-arms,  Alone and palely loitering?  The sedge has withered from the lake,  And no birds sing.

pages.title: To Hope by John Keats
pages.short_description: When by my solitary hearth I sit,  And hateful thoughts enwrap my soul in gloom;  When no fair dreams before my 'mind's eye' flit,  And the bare heath of life presents no bloom;

pages.title: When I have fears that I may cease to be by John Keats
pages.short_description: When I have fears that I may cease to be  Before my pen has glean'd my teeming brain,  Before high piled books, in charact'ry,  Hold like rich garners the full-ripen'd grain;  When I behold, upon the night's starr'd face

pages.title: To Autumn by John Keats
pages.short_description: Season of mists and mellow fruitfulness,   Close bosom-friend of the maturing sun;   Conspiring with him how to load and bless

pages.title: Ode to a Nightingale by John Keats
pages.short_description: My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains  My sense, as though of hemlock I had drunk,   Or emptied some dull opiate to the drains

pages.title: Ode on a Grecian Urn by John Keats
pages.short_description: Thou still unravish'd bride of quietness,   Thou foster-child of silence and slow time,   Sylvan historian, who canst thou express   A flowery tale more sweetly than our rhyme:

pages.title: Bright star! would I were steadfast as thou art by John Keats
pages.short_description: Bright star! would I were steadfast as thou art-   Not in lone splendour hung aloft the night,   And watching, with eternal lids apart,   Like Nature's patient sleepless Eremite

pages.title: The Walrus and the Carpenter by Lewis Carroll
pages.short_description: The sun was shining on the sea,  Shining with all his might:  He did his very best to make  The billows smooth and bright -  And this was odd, because it was  The middle of the night.   The moon was shining sulkily

pages.title: Jabberwocky by Lewis Carroll
pages.short_description: Twas brillig, and the slithy toves  Did gyre and gimble in the wabe:  All mimsy were the borogoves,  And the mome raths outgrabe.   'Beware the Jabberwock, my son!

pages.title: A Dead Friend by Algernon Charles Swinburne
pages.short_description: I.   Gone, O gentle heart and true,  Friend of hopes foregone,  Hopes and hopeful days with you  Gone?   Days of old that shone

pages.title: William Shakespeare by Algernon Charles Swinburne
pages.short_description: Not if men's tongues and angels' all in one Spake, might the word be said that might speak thee. Streams, winds, woods, flowers, fields, mountains, yea, the sea, What power is in them all to praise the sun

pages.title: The Many by Algernon Charles Swinburne
pages.short_description: Greene, garlanded with February's few flowers  Ere March came in with Marlowe's rapturous rage;  Peele, from whose hand the sweet white locks of age

pages.title: Babyhood by Algernon Charles Swinburne
pages.short_description: A baby shines as bright  If winter or if May be  On eyes that keep in sight  A baby.   Though dark the skies or grey be,  It fills our eyes with light,  If midnight or midday be.

pages.title: On the Death of Robert Browning by Algernon Charles Swinburne
pages.short_description: He held no dream worth waking; so he said,  He who stands now on death's triumphal steep,  Awakened out of life wherein we sleep  And dream of what he knows and sees, being dead.  But never death for him was dark or dread;

pages.title: Not A Child by Algernon Charles Swinburne
pages.short_description: I.  'Not a child: I call myself a boy,'  Says my king, with accent stern yet mild,  Now nine years have brought him change of joy;  'Not a child.'   How could reason be so far beguiled,  Err so far from sense's safe employ,  Stray so wide of truth, or run so wild?

pages.title: The Coronet by Andrew Marvell
pages.short_description: When for the Thorns with which I long, too long,  With many a piercing wound,  My Saviours head have crown'd,  I seek with Garlands to redress that Wrong:  Through every Garden, every Mead,  I gather flow'rs

pages.title: To His Coy Mistress by Andrew Marvell
pages.short_description: Had we but world enough, and time,  This coyness, lady, were no crime.

pages.title: The Definition Of Love by Andrew Marvell
pages.short_description: My love is of a birth as rare  As 'tis for object strange and high:  It was begotten by Despair  Upon Impossibility.    Magnanimous Despair alone  Could show me so divine a thing

pages.title: The Garden by Andrew Marvell
pages.short_description: How vainly men themselves amaze  To win the Palm, the Oke, or Bayes;  And their uncessant Labours see  Crown'd from some single Herb or Tree,  Whose short and narrow verged Shade

pages.title: On A Drop Of Dew by Andrew Marvell
pages.short_description: See how the Orient Dew,  Shed from the Bosom of the Morn  Into the blowing Roses,  Yet careless of its Mansion new;   For the clear Region where 'twas born  Round in its self incloses:  And in its little Globes Extent,  Frames as it can its native Element

pages.title: The Mower's Song by Andrew Marvell
pages.short_description: My Mind was once the true survey  Of all these Medows fresh and gay;  And in the greenness of the Grass  Did see its Hopes as in a Glass

pages.title: Annabel Lee by Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: It was many and many a year ago,  In a kingdom by the sea,  That a maiden there lived whom you may know  By the name of Annabel Lee;  And this maiden she lived with no other thought  Than to love and be loved by me.   I was a child and she was a child,  In this kingdom by the sea:  But we loved with a love that was more than love

pages.title: The Raven by Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,   Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore,   While I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping,   As of some one gently rapping, rapping at my chamber door.

pages.title: The Bells by Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: I   Hear the sledges with the bells-  Silver bells!  What a world of merriment their melody foretells!  How they tinkle, tinkle, tinkle,  In the icy air of night!  While the stars that oversprinkle  All the heavens, seem to twinkle

pages.title: A Dream Within A Dream by Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: Take this kiss upon the brow!  And, in parting from you now,  Thus much let me avow--  You are not wrong, who deem  That my days have been a dream;  Yet if hope has flown away  In a night, or in a day,  In a vision, or in none,  Is it therefore the less gone

pages.title: In Youth I have Known One by Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: How often we forget all time, when lone   Admiring Nature's universal throne;   Her woods - her winds - her mountains - the intense   Reply of Hers to Our intelligence!    I.    In youth I have known one with whom the Earth

pages.title: The Fall of the House of Usher By Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: the whole of a dull, dark, and soundless day in the autumn of the year, when the clouds hung oppressively low in the heavens

pages.title: The Murders in the Rue Morgue by Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: THE mental features discoursed of as the analytical, are, in themselves, but little susceptible of analysis. We appreciate them only in their effects. We know of them, among other things, that they are always to their possessor, when inordinately possessed, a source of the liveliest enjoyment. As the strong man exults in his physical ability, delighting in such exercises as call his muscles into action, so glories the analyst in that moral activity which disentangles. He derives pleasure from even the most trivial occupations bringing his talent into play

pages.title: The Tell-Tale Heart by Edgar Allan Poe
pages.short_description: nervous -- very, very dreadfully nervous I had been and am; but why will you say that I am mad? The disease had sharpened my senses -- not destroyed -- not dulled them. Above all was the sense of hearing acute. I heard all things in the heaven and in the earth. I heard many things in hell.

pages.title: The Owl and the Pussy Cat by Edward Lear
pages.short_description: The Owl and the Pussy Cat went to sea  In a beautiful pea-green boat,  They took some honey, and plenty of money  Wrapped up in a five-pound note.  The Owl looked up to the stars above,  And sang to a small guitar

pages.title: The Jumblies by Edward Lear
pages.short_description: I  They went to sea in a Sieve, they did,  In a Sieve they went to sea:  In spite of all their friends could say,  On a winter's morn, on a stormy day

pages.title: There Was an Old Man with a Beard by Edward Lear
pages.short_description: There was an Old Man with a beard,  Who said, 'It is just as I feared! --  Two Owls and a Hen, four Larks and a Wren,  Have all built their nests in my beard.

pages.title: There was a Young Lady Whose Eyes by Edward Lear
pages.short_description: There was a young lady whose eyes,  were unique as to colour and size;  When she opened them wide,  people all turned aside,  and started away in surprise.

pages.title: Canto XLV by Ezra Pound
pages.short_description: With Usura    With usura hath no man a house of good stone  each block cut smooth and well fitting  that design might cover their face,  with usura  hath no man a painted paradise on his church wall

pages.title: A Girl by Ezra Pound
pages.short_description: The tree has entered my hands,   The sap has ascended my arms,   The tree has grown in my breast-   Downward,   The branches grow out of me, like arms.     Tree you are,   Moss you are

pages.title: In A Station Of The Metro by Ezra Pound
pages.short_description: The apparition of these faces in the crowd; Petals on a wet, black bough.

pages.title: Portrait d'Une Femme by Ezra Pound
pages.short_description: Your mind and you are our Sargasso Sea,  London has swept about you this score years  And bright ships left you this or that in fee:  Ideas, old gossip, oddments of all things,  Strange spars of knowledge and dimmed wares of price.

pages.title: The River-Merchant's Wife: A Letter by Ezra Pound
pages.short_description: While my hair was still cut straight   across my forehead  I played at the front gate, pulling  flowers.  You came by on bamboo stilts, playing  horse,  You walked about my seat, playing with  blue plums.   And we went on living in the village of   Chokan:

pages.title: No Worst, There Is None. Pitched Past Pitch Of Grief by Gerard Manley Hopkins
pages.short_description: No worst, there is none. Pitched past pitch of grief,  More pangs will, schooled at forepangs, wilder wring.  Comforter, where, where is your comforting?  Mary, mother of us, where is your relief?

pages.title: God's Grandeur by Gerard Manley Hopkins
pages.short_description: The world is charged with the grandeur of God.  It will flame out, like shining from shook foil;  It gathers to a greatness, like the ooze of oil  Crushed. Why do men then now not reck his rod?  Generations have trod, have trod, have trod;

pages.title: Repeat That, Repeat by Gerard Manley Hopkins
pages.short_description: Repeat that, repeat, Cuckoo, bird, and open ear wells, heart-springs, delightfully sweet, With a ballad, with a ballad, a rebound  Off trundled timber and scoops of the hillside ground, hollow hollow hollow ground:

pages.title: Peace by Gerard Manley Hopkins
pages.short_description: When will you ever, Peace, wild wooddove, shy wings shut,  Your round me roaming end, and under be my boughs?  When, when, Peace, will you, Peace? I'll not play hypocrite  To own my heart: I yield you do come sometimes; but  That piecemeal peace is poor peace. What pure peace allows

pages.title: I Wake And Feel The Fell Of Dark, Not Day by Gerard Manley Hopkins
pages.short_description: I wake and feel the fell of dark, not day.  What hours, O what black hours we have spent  This night! what sights you, heart, saw; ways you went!  And more must, in yet longer light's delay.   With witness I speak this. But where I say  Hours I mean years, mean life. And my lament

pages.title: The Soldier by Gerard Manley Hopkins
pages.short_description: Yes. Why do we all, seeing of a soldier, bless him? Bless Our redcoats, our tars? Both these being, the greater part, But frail clay, nay but foul clay. Here it is: the heart, Since, proud, it calls the calling manly, gives a guess That, hopes that, makesbelieve, the men must be no less; It fancies, feigns, deems, dears the artist after his art; And fain will find as sterling all as all is smart, And scarlet wear the spirit of war there express.

pages.title: As Kingfishers Catch Fire by Gerard Manley Hopkins
pages.short_description: As kingfishers catch fire, dragonflies draw flame; As tumbled over rim in roundy wells Stones ring; like each tucked string tells, each hung bell's Bow swung finds tongue to fling out broad its name; Each mortal thing does one thing and the same:

pages.title: They are all gone into the world of light! by Henry Vaughan
pages.short_description: They are all gone into the world of light!  And I alone sit ling'ring here;  Their very memory is fair and bright,  And my sad thoughts doth clear.   It glows and glitters in my cloudy breast,  Like stars upon some gloomy grove,  Or those faint beams in which this hill is drest,  After the sun's remove.

pages.title: The Revival by Henry Vaughan
pages.short_description: UNFOLD ! unfold ! Take in His light,  Who makes thy cares more short than night.  The joys which with His day-star rise  He deals to all but drowsy eyes ;  And, what the men of this world miss  Some drops and dews of future bliss.

pages.title: The World by Henry Vaughan
pages.short_description: I SAW Eternity the other night,   Like a great ring of pure and endless light,   All calm, as it was bright ;   And round beneath it, Time in hours, days, years   Driv'n by the spheres   Like a vast shadow mov'd ;

pages.title: The Water-Fall by Henry Vaughan
pages.short_description: With what deep murmurs through time's silent stealth  Doth thy transparent, cool, and watery wealth  Here flowing fall,  And chide, and call,  As if his liquid, loose retinue stayed  Lingering, and were of this steep place afraid;

pages.title: Regeneration by Henry Vaughan
pages.short_description: Award, and still in bonds, one day   I stole abroad,   It was high-spring, and all the way   Primros'd, and hung with shade;   Yet, was it frost within,   And surly winds   Blasted my infant buds, and sin

pages.title: How To Get On In Society by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: Phone for the fish knives, Norman  As cook is a little unnerved;  You kiddies have crumpled the serviettes  And I must have things daintily served.   Are the requisites all in the toilet?  The frills round the cutlets can wait  Till the girl has replenished the cruets  And switched on the logs in the grate.

pages.title: Diary of a Church Mouse by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: Here among long-discarded cassocks,  Damp stools, and half-split open hassocks,  Here where the vicar never looks  I nibble through old service books.

pages.title: Christmas by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: The bells of waiting Advent ring,  The Tortoise stove is lit again  And lamp-oil light across the night  Has caught the streaks of winter rain  In many a stained-glass window sheen  From Crimson Lake to Hookers Green.

pages.title: Seaside Golf by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: How straight it flew, how long it flew,  It clear'd the rutty track  And soaring, disappeared from view  Beyond the bunker's back -  A glorious, sailing, bounding drive  That made me glad I was alive

pages.title: Death In Leamington by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: She died in the upstairs bedroom  By the light of the ev'ning star  That shone through the plate glass window  From over Leamington Spa   Beside her the lonely crochet  Lay patiently and unstirred,  But the fingers that would have work'd it  Were dead as the spoken word.

pages.title: The Last Laugh by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: I made hay while the sun shone. My work sold. Now, if the harvest is over And the world cold, Give me the bonus of laughter As I lose hold.

pages.title: A Subaltern's Love Song by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: What strenuous singles we played after tea,  We in the tournament - you against me!   Love-thirty, love-forty, oh! weakness of joy,  The speed of a swallow, the grace of a boy,  With carefullest carelessness, gaily you won,  I am weak from your loveliness, Joan Hunter Dunn   Miss Joan Hunter Dunn, Miss Joan Hunter Dunn,  How mad I am, sad I am, glad that you won,

pages.title: Loneliness by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: The last year's leaves are on the beech:  The twigs are black; the cold is dry;  To deeps byond the deepest reach  The Easter bells enlarge the sky.

pages.title: Business Girls by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: From the geyser ventilators  Autumn winds are blowing down  On a thousand business women  Having baths in Camden Town   Waste pipes chuckle into runnels,  Steam's escaping here and there,  Morning trains through Camden cutting  Shake the Crescent and the Square.   Early nip of changeful autumn,  Dahlias glimpsed through garden doors,  At the back precarious bathrooms

pages.title: Meditation on the A30 by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: A man on his own in a car  Is revenging himself on his wife  He open the throttle and bubbles with dottle  and puffs at his pitiful life   She's losing her looks very fast,  she loses her temper all day

pages.title: In A Bath Teashop by John Betjeman
pages.short_description: Let us not speak, for the love we bear one another- Let us hold hands and look.' She such a very ordinary little woman; He such a thumping crook; But both, for a moment, little lower than the angels

pages.title: Dover Beach by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: The sea is calm to-night.  The tide is full, the moon lies fair  Upon the straits; on the French coast the light  Gleams and is gone; the cliffs of England stand;  Glimmering and vast, out in the tranquil bay

pages.title: The Future by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: A wanderer is man from his birth.  He was born in a ship  On the breast of the river of Time;  Brimming with wonder and joy  He spreads out his arms to the light,  Rivets his gaze on the banks of the stream.

pages.title: Growing Old by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: What is it to grow old?  Is it to lose the glory of the form,  The lustre of the eye?  Is it for beauty to forego her wreath?  Yes, but not for this alone.   Is it to feel our strength-;   Not our bloom only, but our strength-;decay?

pages.title: Longing by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: Come to me in my dreams, and then  By day I shall be well again!  For so the night will more than pay  The hopeless longing of the day.   Come, as thou cam'st a thousand times,  A messenger from radiant climes,  And smile on thy new world, and be  As kind to others as to me

pages.title: To A Friend by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: Who prop, thou ask'st in these bad days, my mind?--  He much, the old man, who, clearest-souled of men,  Saw The Wide Prospect, and the Asian Fen,  And Tmolus hill, and Smyrna bay, though blind.

pages.title: Shakespeare by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: Others abide our question. Thou art free.  We ask and ask-;thou smilest and art still,  Out-topping knowledge. For the loftiest hill,  Who to the stars uncrowns his majesty,   Planting his stedfast footsteps in the sea,  Making the heaven of heavens his dwelling-place,  Spares but the cloudy border of his base  To the foiled searching of mortality;

pages.title: East London by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: Twas August, and the fierce sun overhead  Smote on the squalid streets of Bethnal Green,  And the pale weaver, through his windows seen  In Spitalfields, looked thrice dispirited.  I met a preacher there I knew, and said:

pages.title: The Voice by Matthew Arnold
pages.short_description: As the kindling glances,  Queen-like and clear,  Which the bright moon lances  From her tranquil sphere  At the sleepless waters  Of a lonely mere,  On the wild whirling waves, mournfully, mournfully,  Shiver and die.

pages.title: Fate by Ralph Waldo Emerson
pages.short_description: That you are fair or wise is vain,  Or strong, or rich, or generous;  You must have also the untaught strain  That sheds beauty on the rose.  There is a melody born of melody,  Which melts the world into a sea.

pages.title: Days by Ralph Waldo Emerson
pages.short_description: Daughters of Time, the hypocritic Days,  Muffled and dumb like barefoot dervishes,  And marching single in an endless file,  Bring diadems and fagots in their hands.  To each they offer gifts after his will,  Bread, kingdoms, stars, and sky that holds them all.

pages.title: Celestial Love by Ralph Waldo Emerson
pages.short_description: Higher far,  Upward, into the pure realm,  Over sun or star,  Over the flickering Daemon;mon film,  Thou must mount for love,-;  Into vision which all form  In one only form dissolves;

pages.title: Ode To Beauty by Ralph Waldo Emerson
pages.short_description: Who gave thee, O Beauty!  The keys of this breast,  Too credulous lover  Of blest and unblest?  Say when in lapsed ages  Thee knew I of old;  Or what was the service  For which I was sold?

pages.title: The Apology by Ralph Waldo Emerson
pages.short_description: Think me not unkind and rude,  That I walk alone in grove and glen;  I go to the god of the wood  To fetch his word to men.   Tax not my sloth that I  Fold my arms beside the brook;  Each cloud that floated in the sky  Writes a letter in my book

pages.title: Give All To Love by Ralph Waldo Emerson
pages.short_description: Give all to love;  Obey thy heart;  Friends, kindred, days,  Estate, good fame,  Plans, credit, and the muse;  Nothing refuse.   'Tis a brave master,  Let it have scope,  Follow it utterly,  Hope beyond hope;

pages.title: My Last Duchess by Robert Browning
pages.short_description: That's my last duchess painted on the wall,  Looking as if she were alive. I call  That piece a wonder, now

pages.title: Porphyria's Lover by Robert Browning
pages.short_description: The rain set early in tonight,   The sullen wind was soon awake,   It tore the elm-tops down for spite,   And did its worst to vex the lake:   I listened with heart fit to break.   When glided in Porphyria;

pages.title: The Laboratory by Robert Browning
pages.short_description: I   Now that I, tying thy glass mask tightly,  May gaze through these faint smokes curling whitely,  As thou pliest thy trade in this devil's-smithy-   Which is the poison to poison her, prithee?

pages.title: Home Thoughts, From Abroad by Robert Browning
pages.short_description: Oh, to be in England  Now that April's there,  And whoever wakes in England  Sees, some morning, unaware,  That the lowest boughs and the brushwood sheaf  Round the elm-tree bole are in tiny leaf,  While the chaffinch sings on the orchard bough  In England-now!

pages.title: Love Among The Ruins by Robert Browning
pages.short_description: I   Where the quiet-coloured end of evening smiles  Miles and miles  On the solitary pastures where our sheep  Half-asleep  Tinkle homeward thro' the twilight, stray or stop  As they crop-   Was the site once of a city great and gay,  (So they say)  Of our country's very capital, its prince  Ages since  Held his court in, gathered councils, wielding far  Peace or war.

pages.title: Life In A Love by Robert Browning
pages.short_description: Escape me?  Never-   Beloved!  While I am I, and you are you,  So long as the world contains us both,  Me the loving and you the loth,  While the one eludes, must the other pursue.  My life is a fault at last, I fear-   It seems too much like a fate, indeed!
