pages.title: Love In A Life by Robert Browning
pages.short_description: I   Room after room,  I hunt the house through  We inhabit together.  Heart, fear nothing, for, heart, thou shalt find her,  Next time, herself!-not the trouble behind her  Left in the curtain, the couch's perfume!  As she brushed it, the cornice-wreath blossomed anew,-   Yon looking-glass gleamed at the wave of her feather.

pages.title: A Red, Red Rose by Robert Burns
pages.short_description: O my Luve's like a red, red rose  That's newly sprung in June;  O my Luve's like the melodie  That's sweetly played in tune.   As fair art thou, my bonnie lass,  So deep in luve am I;

pages.title: Coming Through The Rye by Robert Burns
pages.short_description: Coming thro' the rye, poor body,  Coming thro' the rye,  She draiglet a' her petticoatie  Coming thro' the rye.   O, Jenny's a' wat, poor body;  Jenny's seldom dry;  She draiglet a' her petticoatie  Coming thro' the rye.   Gin a body meet a body  Coming thro' the rye,  Gin a body kiss a body-   Need a body cry?

pages.title: To A Mouse by Robert Burns
pages.short_description: On Turning her up in her Nest with the Plough   Wee, sleekit, cow'rin', tim'rous beastie,  O what a panic's in thy breastie!  Thou need na start awa sae hasty,  Wi' bickering brattle

pages.title: Ae Fond Kiss, And Then We Sever by Robert Burns
pages.short_description: Ae fond kiss, and then we sever;  Ae fareweel, and then for ever!  Deep in heart-wrung tears I'll pledge thee,  Warring sighs and groans I'll wage thee.   Who shall say that Fortune grieves him  While the star of hope she leaves him?

pages.title: My Heart's In The Highlands by Robert Burns
pages.short_description: Farewell to the Highlands, farewell to the North,  The birth-place of Valour, the country of Worth;  Wherever I wander, wherever I rove,  The hills of the Highlands for ever I love.   My heart's in the Highlands, my heart is not here;

pages.title: The Soldier by Rupert Brooke
pages.short_description: If I should die, think only this of me:  That there's some corner of a foreign field  That is for ever England.

pages.title: The Old Vicarage, Granchester by Rupert Brooke
pages.short_description: Just now the lilac is in bloom,  All before my little room;  And in my flower-beds, I think,  Smile the carnation and the pink;

pages.title: The Dead by Rupert Brooke
pages.short_description: Blow out, you bugles, over the rich Dead!  There's none of these so lonely and poor of old,  But, dying, has made us rarer gifts than gold.  These laid the world away; poured out the red  Sweet wine of youth;

pages.title: Dining-Room Tea by Rupert Brooke
pages.short_description: When you were there, and you, and you,   Happiness crowned the night; I too,   Laughing and looking, one of all,   I watched the quivering lamplight fall   On plate and flowers and pouring tea  And cup and cloth;

pages.title: Blackberry-Picking by Seamus Heaney
pages.short_description: Late August, given heavy rain and sun  For a full week, the blackberries would ripen.  At first, just one, a glossy purple clot  Among others, red, green, hard as a knot.  You ate that first one and its flesh was sweet  Like thickened wine: summer's blood was in it

pages.title: Digging by Seamus Heaney
pages.short_description: Between my finger and my thumb  The squat pin rest; snug as a gun.   Under my window, a clean rasping sound  When the spade sinks into gravelly ground

pages.title: Death Of A Naturalist by Seamus Heaney
pages.short_description: All year the flax-dam festered in the heart  Of the townland; green and heavy headed  Flax had rotted there, weighted down by huge sods.  Daily it sweltered in the punishing sun.

pages.title: Twice Shy by Seamus Heaney
pages.short_description: Her scarf a la Bardot,   In suede flats for the walk,   She came with me one evening  For air and friendly talk.  We crossed the quiet river,   Took the embankment walk.

pages.title: Casualty by Seamus Heaney
pages.short_description: I   He would drink by himself  And raise a weathered thumb  Towards the high shelf,  Calling another rum  And blackcurrant, without  Having to raise his voice,  Or order a quick stout  By a lifting of the eyes

pages.title: Mid-Term Break by Seamus Heaney
pages.short_description: I sat all morning in the college sick bay  Counting bells knelling classes to a close.  At two o'clock our neighbors drove me home.   In the porch I met my father crying

pages.title: Suicide In The Trenches by Siegfried Sassoon
pages.short_description: I knew a simple soldier boy   Who grinned at life in empty joy,   Slept soundly through the lonesome dark,   And whistled early with the lark.    In winter trenches, cowed and glum,   With crumps and lice and lack of rum,   He put a bullet through his brain.

pages.title: Glory Of Women by Siegfried Sassoon
pages.short_description: You love us when we're heroes, home on leave,   Or wounded in a mentionable place.   You worship decorations; you believe   That chivalry redeems the war's disgrace.   You make us shells. You listen with delight,   By tales of dirt and danger fondly thrilled.

pages.title: Does It Matter? by Siegfried Sassoon
pages.short_description: Does it matter?-losing your legs?  For people will always be kind,  And you need not show that you mind  When others come in after hunting  To gobble their muffins and eggs.  Does it matter?-losing you sight?  There's such splendid work for the blind;

pages.title: The Dug-Out by Siegfried Sassoon
pages.short_description: Why do you lie with your legs ungainly huddled,  And one arm bent across your sullen, cold,  Exhausted face? It hurts my heart to watch you,  Deep-shadowed from the candle's guttering gold;  And you wonder why I shake you by the shoulder;  Drowsy, you mumble and sigh and turn your head

pages.title: Elegy by Siegfried Sassoon
pages.short_description: Your dextrous wit will haunt us long   Wounding our grief with yesterday.   Your laughter is a broken song;   And death has found you, kind and gay

pages.title: Hero by Siegfried Sassoon
pages.short_description: Jack fell as he'd have wished,' the Mother said,  And folded up the letter that she'd read.   'The Colonel writes so nicely.' Something broke  In the tired voice that quavered to a choke.  She half looked up. 'We mothers are so proud  Of our dead

pages.title: The Eagle by Lord Alfred Tennyson
pages.short_description: He clasps the crag with crooked hands; Close to the sun in lonely lands, Ring'd with the azure world, he stands.  The wrinkled sea beneath him crawls; He watches from his mountain walls, And like a thunderbolt he falls.

pages.title: The Lady Of Shalott by Lord Alfred Tennyson
pages.short_description: On either side the river lie  Long fields of barley and of rye,  That clothe the wold and meet the sky;  And thro' the field the road runs by  To many-tower'd Camelot

pages.title: The Charge Of The Light Brigade by Lord Alfred Tennyson
pages.short_description: Half a league, half a league,  Half a league onward,  All in the valley of Death  Rode the six hundred.  'Forward, the Light Brigade!  Charge for the guns!' he said:

pages.title: Ulysses by Lord Alfred Tennyson
pages.short_description: It little profits that an idle king,  By this still hearth, among these barren crags,  Matched with an aged wife, I mete and dole  Unequal laws unto a savage race,  That hoard, and sleep, and feed, and know not me

pages.title: A Farewell by Lord Alfred Tennyson
pages.short_description: Flow down, cold rivulet, to the sea,  Thy tribute wave deliver:  No more by thee my steps shall be,  For ever and for ever.   Flow, softly flow, by lawn and lea,  A rivulet then a river:  Nowhere by thee my steps shall be  For ever and for ever.

pages.title: Let me not to the marriage of true minds by William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: Flow down, cold rivulet, to the sea,  Thy tribute wave deliver:  No more by thee my steps shall be,  For ever and for ever.   Flow, softly flow, by lawn and lea,  A rivulet then a river:  Nowhere by thee my steps shall be  For ever and for ever.

pages.title: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? By William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?   Thou art more lovely and more temperate.   Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,   And summer's lease hath all too short a date.

pages.title: Th' Expense Of Spirit In A Waste Of Shame by William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: Th' expense of spirit in a waste of shame  Is lust in action; and till action, lust  Is perjured, murderous, bloody, full of blame,  Savage, extreme, rude, cruel, not to trust

pages.title: Not Marble, Nor The Gilded Monuments by William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: Not marble, nor the gilded monuments  Of princes, shall outlive this powerful rhyme;  But you shall shine more bright in these contents  Than unswept stone, besmeared with sluttish time.

pages.title: That Time Of Year Thou Mayst In Me Behold by William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: That time of year thou mayst in me behold  When yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang  Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,  Bare ruined choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.

pages.title: My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun by William Shakespeare
pages.short_description: My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun;  Coral is far more red than her lips' red;

pages.title: I wandered lonely as a cloud by William Wordsworth
pages.short_description: I wandered lonely as a cloud  That floats on high o'er vales and hills,  When all at once I saw a crowd,  A host, of golden daffodils;  Beside the lake, beneath the trees,  Fluttering and dancing in the breeze.

pages.title: Composed Upon Westminster Bridge  by William Wordsworth
pages.short_description: Earth has not anything to show more fair:  Dull would he be of soul who could pass by  A sight so touching in its majesty:  This City now doth like a garment wear  The beauty of the morning

pages.title: Lines Written In Early Spring by William Wordsworth
pages.short_description: I heard a thousand blended notes,  While in a grove I sate reclined,  In that sweet mood when pleasant thoughts  Bring sad thoughts to the mind.   To her fair works did Nature link  The human soul that through me ran;  And much it grieved my heart to think  What man has made of man.

pages.title: London, 1802 by William Wordsworth
pages.short_description: Milton! thou should'st be living at this hour:  England hath need of thee: she is a fen  Of stagnant waters: altar, sword, and pen,  Fireside, the heroic wealth of hall and bower,  Have forfeited their ancient English dower  Of inward happiness.

pages.title: anyone lived in a pretty how town by E. E. Cummings
pages.short_description: anyone lived in a pretty how town  (with up so floating many bells down)  spring summer autumn winter  he sang his didn't he danced his did.

pages.title: next to of course god america I by E.E. Cummings
pages.short_description: next to of course god america i love you land of the pilgrims' and so forth oh say can you see by the dawn's early my country tis of centuries come and go and are no more what of it we should worry in every language even deafanddumb

pages.title: since feeling is first by E.E. Cummings
pages.short_description: since feeling is first  who pays any attention  to the syntax of things  will never wholly kiss you;  wholly to be a fool  while Spring is in the world   my blood approves,  and kisses are a better fate  than wisdom  lady i swear by all flowers

pages.title: somewhere I have never travelled by E.E. Cummings
pages.short_description: somewhere I have never travelled, gladly beyond  any experience, your eyes have their silence:  in your most frail gesture are things which enclose me,  or which i cannot touch because they are too near

pages.title: my father moved through dooms of love by E.E. Cummings
pages.short_description: my father moved through dooms of love  through sames of am through haves of give,  singing each morning out of each night  my father moved through depths of height   this motionless forgetful where  turned at his glance to shining here

pages.title: Sonnet 43 by Elizabeth Barrett Browning
pages.short_description: How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.  I love thee to the depth and breadth and height  My soul can reach, when feeling out of sight  For the ends of Being and ideal Grace.  I love thee to the level of everday's  Most quiet need, by sun and candlelight.

pages.title: The Weakest Thing by Elizabeth Barrett Browning
pages.short_description: Which is the weakest thing of all  Mine heart can ponder?  The sun, a little cloud can pall  With darkness yonder?  The cloud, a little wind can move  Where'er it listeth?  The wind, a little leaf above,  Though sere, resisteth?

pages.title: Grief by Elizabeth Barrett Browning
pages.short_description: I tell you hopeless grief is passionless,  That only men incredulous of despair,  Half-taught in anguish, through the midnight air  Beat upward to God's throne in loud access  Of shrieking and reproach. Full desertness  In souls, as countries, lieth silent-bare  Under the blanching, vertical eye-glare  Of the absolute heavens

pages.title: The Best Thing In The World by Elizabeth Barrett Browning
pages.short_description: What's the best thing in the world?   June-rose, by May-dew impearled;   Sweet south-wind, that means no rain;   Truth, not cruel to a friend;   Pleasure, not in haste to end;   Beauty, not self-decked and curled   Till its pride is over-plain;

pages.title: The Cry Of The Children by Elizabeth Barrett Browning
pages.short_description: Do ye hear the children weeping, O my brothers,  Ere the sorrow comes with years?  They are leaning their young heads against their mothers,  And that cannot stop their tears.

pages.title: Sea Poppies by Hilda Doolittle
pages.short_description: Amber husk   fluted with gold,   fruit on the sand   marked with a rich grain,    treasure   spilled near the shrub-pines   to bleach on the boulders

pages.title: Adonis by Hilda Doolittle
pages.short_description: Each of us like you   has died once,   has passed through drift of wood-leaves,   cracked and bent   and tortured and unbent   in the winter-frost,   the burnt into gold points,   lighted afresh,   crisp amber, scales of gold-leaf,   gold turned and re-welded

pages.title: Leda by Hilda Doolittle
pages.short_description: Where the slow river   meets the tide,   a red swan lifts red wings   and darker beak,   and underneath the purple down   of his soft breast   uncurls his coral feet.

pages.title: Helen by Hilda Doolittle
pages.short_description: All Greece hates  the still eyes in the white face,  the lustre as of olives  where she stands,  and the white hands.   All Greece reviles  the wan face when she smiles,  hating it deeper still   when it grows wan and white,  remembering past enchantments  and past ills.

pages.title: Stars Wheel in Purple by Hilda Doolittle
pages.short_description: Stars wheel in purple, yours is not so rare  as Hesperus, nor yet so great a star  as bright Aldeboran or Sirius,  nor yet the stained and brilliant one of War;

pages.title: Sea Rose by Hilda Doolittle
pages.short_description: Rose, harsh rose,   marred and with stint of petals,   meagre flower, thin,   sparse of leaf,     more precious   than a wet rose   single on a stem --   you are caught in the drift

pages.title: The Sun Rising by John Donne
pages.short_description: Busy old fool, unruly sun,  Why dost thou thus,  Through windows and through curtains call on us?  Must to thy motions lover's seasons run?

pages.title: The Flea by John Donne
pages.short_description: Mark but this flea, and mark in this  How little that which thou deniest me is;  It sucked me first, and now sucks thee,  And this flea our two bloods mingled be.

pages.title: A Valediction: Forbidding Mourning by John Donne
pages.short_description: As virtuous men pass mildly away,  And whisper to their souls to go,  Whilst some of their sad friends do say  The breath goes now, and some say, No:

pages.title: The Good Morrow by John Donne
pages.short_description: I wonder, by my troth, what thou and I  Did, till we loved? were we not weaned till then,  But sucked on country pleasures, childishly?  Or snorted we in the seven sleepers' den?

pages.title: Holy Sonnet X: Death Be Not Proud by John Donne
pages.short_description: Death, be not proud, though some have called thee  Mighty and dreadful, for thou art not so;  For those whom thou think'st thou dost overthrow  Die not, poor death, nor yet canst thou kill me.

pages.title: Holy Sonnet XIV: Batter My Heart, Three-Personed God by John Donne
pages.short_description: Batter my heart, three-personed God; for you  As yet but knock, breathe, shine, and seek to mend;  That I may rise and stand, o'erthrow me, and bend  Your force to break, blow, burn, and make me new.

pages.title: The Ecstasy by John Donne
pages.short_description: Where, like a pillow on a bed  A pregnant bank swell'd up to rest  The violet's reclining head,  Sat we two, one another's best.  Our hands were firmly cemented  With a fast balm, which thence did spring;

pages.title: Hymn to Intellectual Beauty by Percy Bysshe Shelley
pages.short_description: The awful shadow of some unseen Power  Floats though unseen among us; visiting  This various world with as inconstant wing  As summer winds that creep from flower to flower;  Like moonbeams that behind some piny mountain shower,   It visits with inconstant glance  Each human heart and countenance

pages.title: The Two Spirits: An Allegory by Percy Bysshe Shelley
pages.short_description: FIRST SPIRIT  O thou, who plum'd with strong desire  Wouldst float above the earth, beware!  A Shadow tracks thy flight of fire--  Night is coming!

pages.title: Ozymandias by Percy Bysshe Shelley
pages.short_description: I met a traveller from an antique land  Who said: Two vast and trunkless legs of stone  Stand in the desert. Near them on the sand,  Half sunk, a shatter'd visage lies, whose frown  And wrinkled lip and sneer of cold command

pages.title: England in 1819 by Percy Bysshe Shelley
pages.short_description: An old, mad, blind, despised, and dying king

pages.title: To a Skylark by Percy Bysshe Shelley
pages.short_description: An old, mad, blind, despised, and dying king,--  Princes, the dregs of their dull race, who flow  Through public scorn, mud from a muddy spring,--  Rulers who neither see, nor feel, nor know,  But leech-like to their fainting country cling,  Till they drop, blind in blood, without a blow

pages.title: Christabel by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
pages.short_description: Tis the middle of night by the castle clock  And the owls have awakened the crowing cock;  Tu-whit!- Tu-whoo!  And hark, again! the crowing cock,  How drowsily it crew.  Sir Leoline, the Baron rich,  Hath a toothless mastiff, which  From her kennel beneath the rock  Maketh answer to the clock,  Four for the quarters, and twelve for the hour;

pages.title: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
pages.short_description: It is an ancient Mariner,  And he stoppeth one of three.  'By thy long grey beard and glittering eye,  Now wherefore stopp'st thou me?   The bridegroom's doors are opened wide,  And I am next of kin;

pages.title: Epigram by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
pages.short_description: Sir, I admit your general rule, That every poet is a fool, But you yourself may serve to show it, That every fool is not a poet.

pages.title: Work Without Hope by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
pages.short_description: All Nature seems at work. Slugs leave their lair-  The bees are stirring-birds are on the wing-  And Winter slumbering in the open air,  Wears on his smiling face a dream of Spring!

pages.title: Frost at Midnight by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
pages.short_description: The Frost performs its secret ministry,  Unhelped by any wind. The owlet's cry  Came loud, -and hark, again! loud as before.  The inmates of my cottage, all at rest,  Have left me to that solitude, which suits  Abstruser musings: save that at my side  My cradled infant slumbers peacefully.

pages.title: Kubla Khan by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
pages.short_description: In Xanadu did Kubla Khan  A stately pleasure-dome decree:  Where Alph, the sacred river, ran  Through caverns measureless to man  Down to a sunless sea.

pages.title: This Lime-Tree Bower, My Prison by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
pages.short_description: Well, they are gone, and here must I remain,  This lime-tree bower my prison! I have lost  Beauties and feelings, such as would have been  Most sweet to my remembrance even when age  Had dimm'd mine eyes to blindness!

pages.title: The Pleasures Of Friendship by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: The pleasures of friendship are exquisite, How pleasant to go to a friend on a visit! I go to my friend, we walk on the grass, And the hours and moments like minutes pass.

pages.title: Not Waving But Drowning by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: Nobody heard him, the dead man,  But still he lay moaning:  I was much further out than you thought  And not waving but drowning

pages.title: Alone In The Woods by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: Alone in the woods I felt  The bitter hostility of the sky and the trees  Nature has taught her creatures to hate  Man that fusses and fumes  Unquiet man  As the sap rises in the trees  As the sap paints the trees a violent green

pages.title: Never Again by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: Never again will I weep  And wring my hands  And beat my head against the wall  Because  Me nolentem fata trahunt  But  When I have had enough  I will arise  And go unto my Father

pages.title: Drugs Made Pauline Vague by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: Drugs made Pauline vague.  She sat one day at the breakfast table  Fingering in a baffled way  The fronds of the maidenhair plant.    Was it the salt you were looking for dear?

pages.title: I Do Not Speak by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: I do not ask for mercy for understanding for peace  And in these heavy days I do not ask for release  I do not ask that suffering shall cease

pages.title: I Remember by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: It was my bridal night I remember,  An old man of seventy-three  I lay with my young bride in my arms,  A girl with t.b.  It was wartime, and overhead  The Germans were making a particularly heavy raid on  Hampstead.

pages.title: Lady 'Rogue' Singleton by Stevie Smith
pages.short_description: Come, wed me, Lady Singleton,   And we will have a baby soon   And we will live in Edmonton   Where all the friendly people run.   I could never make you happy, darling,   Or give you the baby that you want,   I would always very much rather, dear,   Live in a tent.

pages.title: The Garden Party By Katherine Mansfield
pages.short_description: And after all the weather was ideal. They could not have had a more perfect day for a garden-party if they had ordered it. Windless, warm, the sky without a cloud

pages.title: At the Bay by Katharine Mansfield
pages.short_description: “Make it a rule of life never to regret and never to look back. Regret is an appalling waste of energy; you can't build on it; it's only good for wallowing in.” Katherine Mansfield

pages.title: Kew Gardens by Virginia Woolf
pages.short_description: After they had scrutinized the old man's back in silence for a moment and given each other a queer, sly look, they went on energetically piecing together their very complicated dialogue

pages.title: The Odour of Chrysanthemums by D. H. Lawrence
pages.short_description: She worked at her sewing with energy, listening to the children, and her anger wearied itself, lay down to rest, opening its eyes from time to time and steadily watching, its ears raised to listen. Sometimes even her anger quailed and shrank, and the mother suspended her sewing

pages.title: The Rocking-Horse Winner by D.H. Lawrence
pages.short_description: The mother had a small income, and the father had a small income, but not nearly enough for the social position which they had to keep up.

pages.title: The Dead by James Joyce
pages.short_description: “Moments of their secret life together burst like stars upon his memory.” James Joyce, The Dead

pages.title: The Story of an Hour by Kate Chopin
pages.short_description: She did not hear the story as many women have heard the same, with a paralyzed inability to accept its significance.

pages.title: Athenaise by Kate Chopin
pages.short_description: “There were sudden glimpses of a bayou curling between sunny, grassy banks.

pages.title: Rip Van Winkle by  Washington Irving
pages.short_description: “But what courage can withstand the ever-during and all-besetting terrors of a woman's tongue?” Washington Irving, Rip Van Winkle

pages.title: The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Washington Irving
pages.short_description: A drowsy, dreamy influence seems to hang over the land, and to pervade the very atmosphere. Some say that the place was bewitched by a high German doctor, during the early days of the settlement; others, that an old Indian chief, the prophet or wizard of his tribe, held his powwows there before the country was discovered by Master Hendrick Hudson.

pages.title: The Devoted Friend by Oscar Wilde
pages.short_description: “Every good story-teller nowadays starts with the end, and then goes on to the beginning, and concludes with themiddle...” Oscar Wilde, The Devoted Friend

pages.title: Amy Foster by Joseph Conrad
pages.short_description: “For you need imagination to form a notion of beauty at all, and still more to discover your ideal in an unfamiliar shape.” Joseph Conrad, Amy Foster

pages.title: The Lagoon by Joseph Conrad
pages.short_description: “A writing may be lost; a lie may be written; but what the eye has seen is truth and remains in the mind!” Joseph Conrad, The Lagoon

pages.title: An Outpost Of Progress by Joseph Conrad
pages.short_description: “Society was calling to its accomplished child to come, to be taken care of, to be instructed, to be judged, to be condemned; it called him to return to that rubbish heap from which he had wandered away, so that justice could be done.” Joseph Conrad, Outpost of Progress

pages.title: The Secret Sharer by Joseph Conrad
pages.short_description: But what I felt most was my being a stranger to the ship; and if all truth must be told, I was somewhat of a stranger to myself

pages.title: The Country of the Blind by H. G. Wells
pages.short_description: An early settler who chanced to be outside the valley when the earthquake occurred was never able to return. Before he died, he described the place whence he came. A place where it never rained or snowed, it was a virtual utopia until a strange disease rendered everyone blind. Because people then considered sin to be the cause of disease, the settler was chosen to leave the valley to find priests to build a shrine that would buy holy help from the blindness. The mountain moved, however, so the settler could never return.

pages.title: The Star by H. G. Wells
pages.short_description: How small the vastest of human catastrophes may seem at a distance of a few million miles.

pages.title: The Truth About Pyecraft by H. G. Wells
pages.short_description: He sits not a dozen yards away. If I glance over my shoulder I can see him. And if I catch his eye--and usually I catch his eye-- it meets me with an expression.It is mainly an imploring look--and yet with suspicion in it.

pages.title: The Dilettante by Edith Wharton
pages.short_description: There are two ways of spreading light: to be the candle or the mirror that reflects it. Edith Wharton

pages.title: Souls Belated by Edith Wharton
pages.short_description: Beware of monotony; it's the mother of all the deadly sins. Edith Wharton

pages.title: Xingu by Edith Wharton
pages.short_description: Mrs. Ballinger is one of the ladies who pursue Culture in bands, as though it were dangerous to meet alone. To this end she had founded the Lunch Club, an association composed of herself and several other indomitable huntresses of erudition.

pages.title: The Angel at the Grave by Edith Wharton
pages.short_description: The House stood a few yards back from the elm-shaded village street

pages.title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button by F. Scott Fitzgerald
pages.short_description: Our lives are defined by opportunities, even the ones we miss.

pages.title: The Diamond as Big as the Ritz by F. Scott Fitzgerald
pages.short_description: “Then she added in a sort of childish delight: 'We'll be poor, won't we? Like people in books. And I'll be an orphan and utterly free. Free and poor! What fun!' She stopped and raised her lips to him in a delighted kiss.

pages.title: The Ice Palace by F. Scott Fitzgerald
pages.short_description: “I’m not sure what I’ll do, but— well, I want to go places and see people. I want my mind to grow. I want to live where things happen on a big scale.” F. Scott Fitzgerald, The Ice Palace and Other Stories

pages.title: The Pupil by Henry James
pages.short_description: “It seemed to him that he both knew too much to imagine [the child's] simplicity and too little to disembroil his tangle.” Henry James, The Pupil

pages.title: The Beast in the Jungle by Henry James
pages.short_description: “When the possibilities themselves had accordingly turned stale, when the secret of the gods had grown faint, had perhaps even quite evaporated, that, and that only, was failure. It wouldn’t have been failure to be bankrupt, dishonoured, pilloried, hanged; it was failure not to be anything.” Henry James, Beast in the Jungle

pages.title: The Turn of the Screw by Henry James
pages.short_description: “No, no—there are depths, depths! The more I go over it, the more I see in it, and the more I see in it, the more I fear. I don’t know what I don’t see—what I don’t fear!” Henry James, The Turn of the Screw

pages.title: Nana by Emilie Zola
pages.short_description: “All of a sudden, in the good-natured child, the woman stood revealed, a disturbing woman with all the impulsive madness of her sex, opening the gates of the unknown world of desire. Nana was still smiling, but with the deadly smile of a man-eater.” Émile Zola, Nana

pages.title: The Miller's Daughter by Emile Zola
pages.short_description: “If you ask me what I came to do in this world, I, an artist, will answer you: I am here to live out loud.” Émile Zola

pages.title: Captain Burle by Emile Zola
pages.short_description: “You'd never get Burle to behave decently. When a man sank as low as that, the only thing to do was to throw a spadeful of mud over him and get rid of him like the rotting carcass of some poisonous beast. And even if you shoved his nose in his own shit, he'd only start again the next day and end up stealing a few sous to buy sticks of barley sugar for lice-ridden little beggar-girls.” Émile Zola

pages.title: The Death of Olivier Becaille by Emile Zola
pages.short_description: Buried alive. Could there be nothing more bone-chilling? Olivier Becaille is a plain little man of not much consequence aside from the fact that he is subject to periodic blackouts, a condition known nowadays as syncope. Unfortunately, at that time, no one really knew about this condition.

pages.title: The $30,000 Bequest by Mark Twain
pages.short_description: Lakeside was a pleasant little town of five or six thousand inhabitants, and a rather pretty one, too, as towns go in the Far West. It had church accommodations for thirty-five thousand, which is the way of the Far West and the South, where everybody is religious, and where each of the Protestant sects is represented and has a plant of its own.

pages.title: The Man that Corrupted Hadleyburg by Mark Twain
pages.short_description: “The weakest of all weak things is a virtue which has not been tested in the fire.” Mark Twain, The Man That Corrupted Hadleyburg

pages.title: Alyosha the Pot by Leo Tolstoy
pages.short_description: about the life and death of a simple, uncomplaining worker. Tolstoy centers the story on his meekness, aloofness, and foolishness. Alyosha's simple life, soft-spoken manner, and calm acceptance of death epitomizes Tolstoyan principles.

pages.title: Ivan The Fool by Leo Tolstoy
pages.short_description: In a certain kingdom there lived a rich peasant, who had three sons--Simeon (a soldier), Tarras-Briukhan (fat man), and Ivan (a fool)--and one daughter, Milania, born dumb. Simeon went to war, to serve the Czar; Tarras went to a city and became a merchant; and Ivan, with his sister, remained at home to work on the farm.

pages.title: God Sees The Truth, But Waits by Leo Tolstoy
pages.short_description: The story, about a man sent to prison for a murder he didn't commit, takes the form of a parable of forgiveness.

pages.title: A Terribly Strange Bed by Wilkie Collins
pages.short_description: In the story, an English visitor to a gambling-house in Paris stays overnight in the building, and is nearly killed by a specially constructed bed. A Terribly Strange Bed is a short story by Wilkie Collins, first published in 1852 in Household Words, a magazine edited by Charles Dickens.

pages.title: The Fatal Cradle by Wilkie Collins
pages.short_description: My Weight has been the grand misfortune of my life.

pages.title: The Biter Bit by Wilkie Collins
pages.short_description: This is to inform you that you are wanted to assist in looking up a case of importance, which will require all the attention of an experienced member of the force. The matter of the robbery on which you are now engaged you will please to shift over to the young man who brings you this letter. You will tell him all the circumstances of the case, just as they stand

pages.title: The Dead Hand by Wilkie Collins
pages.short_description: Arthur Holliday, happened to arrive in the town of Doncaster exactly in the middle of the race-week, or, in other words, in the middle of the month of September.  He was one of those reckless, rattlepated, openhearted, and open-mouthed young gentlemen who possess the gift of familiarity in its highest perfection, and who scramble carelessly along the journey of life

pages.title: A Simple Soul by Gustave Flaubert
pages.image: To see all my photos, sear.jpg
pages.short_description: There is no truth. There is only perception. Gustave Flaubert

pages.title: Young Goodman Brown by Nathaniel Hawthorne
pages.short_description: With this excellent resolve for the future, Goodman Brown felt himself justified in making more haste on his present evil purpose.

pages.title: The Birthmark by Nathaniel Hawthorne
pages.short_description: To explain this conversation it must be mentioned that in the centre of Georgiana's left cheek there was a singular mark, deeply interwoven, as it were, with the texture and substance of her face.

pages.title: Ethan Brand by Nathaniel Hawthorne
pages.short_description: “Laughter, when out of place, mistimed, or bursting forth from a disordered state of feeling, may be the most terrible modulation of the human voice.” Nathaniel Hawthorne, Ethan Brand

pages.title: The Three Strangers by Thomas Hardy
pages.short_description: “He's the man we were in search of, that's true, and yet he's not the man we were in search of. For the man we were in search of was not the man we wanted.” Thomas Hardy, Three Strangers And Other Stories

pages.title: The Fiddler of the Reels by Thomas Hardy
pages.short_description: In the story, set in South Wessex and London, the interaction of the lives of three people are related, at the time of the Great Exhibition in London, and of the coming of the railway to Wessex.

pages.title: In the Ravine by Anton Chekhov
pages.short_description: A tale of evil and morality.

pages.title: My Life: The Story of a Provincial by Anton Chekhov
pages.short_description: If anyone is sincere then they are right

pages.title: The End of Something by Ernest Hemingway
pages.short_description: The story is about not only the end of something, but the end of three things: the end of the industry in the area (logging), the end of the mill town, and the end of a relationship.

pages.title: Hills like white elephants by Ernest Hemingway
pages.short_description: I feel fine…There’s nothing wrong with me. I feel fine. Jig, Hills Like White Elephants

pages.title: How Much Land Does A Man Need? by Leo Tolstoy
pages.short_description: Tolstoys story about a man who, in his lust for land, forfeits everything.

pages.title: Wilkie Collins
pages.short_description: “The best men are not consistent in good—why should the worst men be consistent in evil?” Wilkie Collins, The Woman in White

pages.title: Nathaniel Hawthorne

pages.title: Death
pages.short_description: Here was a man who now for the first time found himself looking into the eyes of death--who was passing through one of those rare moments of experience when we feel the truth of a commonplace, which is as different from what we call knowing it, as the vision of waters upon the earth is different from the delirious vision of the water which cannot be had to cool the burning tongue. When the commonplace 'We must all die' transforms itself suddenly into the acute consciousness 'I must die--and soon,' then death grapples us, and his fingers are cruel; afterwards, he may come to fold us in his arms as our mother did, and our last moment of dim earthly discerning may be like the first.GEORGE ELIOT, Middlemarch

pages.short_description: I have a dream that one day even the state of Mississippi, a state sweltering with the heat of injustice, sweltering with the heat of oppression, will be transformed into an oasis of freedom and justice. Martin Luther King Jr.

pages.title: Art and Language
pages.short_description: Every book, every volume you see here, has a soul. The soul of the person who wrote it and of those who read it and lived and dreamed with it. Every time a book changes hands, every time someone runs his eyes down its pages, its spirit grows and strengthens. CARLOS RUIZ ZAFON, The Shadow of the Wind

pages.title: Nature and Beauty
pages.short_description: Beauty awakens the soul to act.Dante Alighieri

pages.title: Madness, Memory and Reality
pages.short_description: “Show me a sane man and I will cure him for you.” C. G. Jung

pages.title: Man and Gender
pages.short_description: “What would men be without women? Scarce, sir...mighty scarce.” Mark Twain

pages.title: Morality, Reputation and Spirit
pages.short_description: The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.” Martin Luther King Jr.

pages.title: Equal Rights and The Other
pages.short_description: “The only stable state is the one in which all men are equal before the law.” Aristotle

pages.title: Life and Conciousness
pages.short_description: Life is a series of natural and spontaneous changes. Don't resist them - that only creates sorrow. Let reality be reality. Let things flow naturally forward in whatever way they like. Lao Tzu

pages.title: Power and Judgement
pages.short_description: Power without love is reckless and abusive, and love without power is sentimental and anemic. Power at its best is love implementing the demands of justice, and justice at its best is power correcting everything that stands against love.” Martin Luther King Jr.

pages.title: Winter Visions
pages.short_description: I wonder if the snow loves the trees and fields, that it kisses them so gently? And then it covers them up snug, you know, with a white quilt, and perhaps it says, Go to sleep, darlings, till the summer comes again. Lewis Carroll in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland & Through the Looking-Glass

pages.title: Motherhood and Family
pages.short_description: “There's no bitch on earth like a mother frightened for her kids.” Stephen King

pages.title: Noir Visuals
pages.short_description: ‘I think there are specific times where film noir is a natural concomitant of the mood. When there's insecurity, collapse of financial systems - that's where film noir always hits fertile ground.’ Werner Herzog

pages.title: Noir
pages.short_description: “Imagine a society that subjects people to conditions that make them terribly unhappy then gives them the drugs to take away their unhappiness. Science fiction It is already happening to some extent in our own society. Instead of removing the conditions that make people depressed modern society gives them antidepressant drugs. In effect antidepressants are a means of modifying an individual's internal state in such a way as to enable him to tolerate social conditions that he would otherwise find intolerable.” Erich Fromm

pages.title: Dissatisfaction and Noir
pages.short_description: ‘I think there are specific times where film noir is a natural concomitant of the mood. When there's insecurity, collapse of financial systems - that's where film noir always hits fertile ground.’ Werner Herzog

pages.title: Noir, Sorrow, Death and Revenge
pages.short_description: “Freddie experienced the sort of abysmal soul-sadness which afflicts one of Tolstoy's Russian peasants when, after putting in a heavy day's work strangling his father, beating his wife, and dropping the baby into the city's reservoir, he turns to the cupboards, only to find the vodka bottle empty.” P.G. Wodehouse, The Best of Wodehouse An Anthology

pages.title: About
pages.short_description: “Alone we can do so little; together we can do so much” helen keller

pages.title: Talent/Commissions
pages.short_description: Any human anywhere will blossom in a hundred unexpected talents and capacities simply by being given the opportunity to do so.Doris Lessing

pages.title: Genre
pages.short_description: “All good books are alike in that they are truer than if they had really happened and after you are finished reading one you will feel that all that happened to you and afterwards it all belongs to you: the good and the bad, the ecstasy, the remorse and sorrow, the people and the places and how the weather was. If you can get so that you can give that to people, then you are a writer.” Ernest Hemingway

pages.title: Novellas
pages.short_description: “A good novel tells us the truth about its hero; but a bad novel tells us the truth about its author.” G.K. Chesterton, Heretics

pages.title: Stories
pages.short_description: Books are not absolutely dead things, but do contain a potency of life in them to be as active as that soul was whose progeny they are; nay they do preserve as in a vial the purest efficacy and extraction of that living intellect that bred them.JOHN MILTON, Areopagitica

pages.title: Authors
pages.short_description: “All good books are alike in that they are truer than if they had really happened and after you are finished reading one you will feel that all that happened to you and afterwards it all belongs to you: the good and the bad, the ecstasy, the remorse and sorrow, the people and the places and how the weather was. If you can get so that you can give that to people, then you are a writer.” Ernest Hemingway

pages.title: Heroes
pages.short_description: The noir hero is a knight in blood caked armour. He's dirty and he does his best to deny the fact that he is a hero the whole time. Frank Miller

pages.title: Time
pages.short_description: “Here we are, trapped in the amber of the moment. There is no why.” Kurt Vonnegut

pages.title: Spirit
pages.short_description: It is not the strength of the body that counts, but the strength of the spirit.” J.R.R. Tolkien

pages.title: Family
pages.short_description: In every conceivable manner, the family is link to our past, bridge to our future.Alex Haley

pages.title: Money
pages.short_description: Money is our madness, our vast collective madness.D. H. Lawrence

pages.title: Journey
pages.short_description: It is good to have an end to journey toward; but it is the journey that matters, in the end. Ernest Hemingway

pages.title: Society
pages.short_description: Society is inside of man and man is inside society, and you cannot even create a truthfully drawn psychological entity on the stage until you understand his social relations and their power to make him what he is and to prevent him from being what he is not. The fish is in the water and the water is in the fish.ARTHUR MILLER, The Shadows of the Gods

pages.title: Noir
pages.short_description: “The rain fell like dead bullets.” Scott Nicholson

pages.title: Beauty of Life
pages.short_description: Everything has beauty, but not everyone sees it. Confucius

pages.title: Chaos
pages.short_description: Chaos does not mean total disorder. Chaos means a multiplicity of possibilities. Chaos is from the ancient Greek words that means a thing that is birthed from the void. And it was about that which is possible, not about disorder.

pages.title: Equal Rights
pages.short_description: “The only stable state is the one in which all men are equal before the law.” Aristotle

pages.title: Women
pages.short_description: Any time women come together with a collective intention, it's a powerful thing. Whether it's sitting down making a quilt, in a kitchen preparing a meal, in a club reading the same book, or around the table playing cards, or planning a birthday party, when women come together with a collective intention, magic happens. Phylicia Rashad
